reviewText:
Who needs the walking dead, malevolent entities or gruesome, face eating aliens when you have South Central L.A.?

Here's the scoop. Brian Taylor (Jake Gyllenhaal) and his partner Mike Zavala (Michael Pena) run a black and white in South Central L.A.. Brian is former military and recording video of their day to day on the job. He's obviously too smart for the job and will probably move up to detective. He has a great relationship with his partner Zavala. They can rib each other endlessly without taking offence. Most days are run of the mill, but they run into some situations that are awful and terrifying. What makes these situations so horror filled is that they are true to life. One thread begins to unravel a sweater too large for them to handle and it leads to a violent conclusion.

What little I read of the movie before going in did not prepare me for what I was about to see. I expected more of a traditionally filmed narrative with a well written script and an A to B to C plot-line. Nope. What I got was all hand-held camera with nearly no plot-line at all. This is a slice o' lifer through and through. You do not feel as though you are watching a film. It's more as though you're with them on their daily routine. There is an immediacy to it all. You are seeing what they are seeing when they see it and at times it's unsettling. There are a lot of crazy, mean, degenerates out there that are drug heads, gang-bangers, and people who deal in the worst of businesses. These cops come across them in their day to day and you wonder how they keep their heads on straight. You come to love and respect these two as the movie rolls on. There were some nice touches as well. When you meet Gyllenhaal's girlfriend/fiance (Anna Kendrick) she's a hoot.  She has a masters degree in fluid dynamics but she's not a stick in the mud. She gets down, and when the two of them perform their dance routine at their wedding, it's something to see.

I cannot say I'm the biggest fan of the police. I'm sure there is little doubt that some of the ills in society could not exist without their help. There are a lot of bad cops out there but here you get to see two guys who are just "on the job" and the stuff they have to put up with. I've gained a whole new respect for the good guys. There are some things that happen in the movie that run into the area of cliche, which is why I haven't given this the big 5 stars, but it has a tremendous amount of impact and will both frighten you and, at times, make your skin crawl. At a reported $7,000,000.00 budget the end far outweighs the dollars put in. If you're at all disposed to this kind of film, put this on your list. It's more than worth your time.

"End of Watch" is a police crime drama from David Ayer who previous wrote movies like "Fast and Furious" and more similarly "Training Day". The real crime show feel of his "Training Day" and "End of Watch" movies seem to be his niche because he's real good at it. With his police crime drama's, you don't get the typical Hollywood police movie, you get something that borders on real. You truly feel like you are on the beat in the middle of some of the worst Los Angeles neighborhood's possible.

"End of Watch" introduces us to Brian Taylor (Jake Gyllenhaal) and Mike Zavala (Michael Pena) as they ride in their police cruiser. We see their world from a dash camera and a camera that Taylor carries with him to document his world, or basically to screw around with. I'm not a big fan of shaky-cam movies, but in this situation, it works because it lends to the effect of realism and adds to the tension you feel as they confront their work. Not to mention, the shaky cam isn't all the time, just when needed or it adds to the events.

"End of Watch" is a buddy movie that could be deemed a comedy if you wanted to, although truthfully, it is just real. As the officers ride around we experience real life. We experience what officers who spend day in and day out in a car together talk about. We get to know them this way. We get to know their intelligence, their home lives, their sense of humor and the conversations are frank and honest, just like the violence and the action throughout the film.

As we watch Taylor and Zavala's bravery and learn who they are and who they have waiting for them at the end of their days, the events of the film become even more tense. Through a random course of events, they eventually pull the waging tail of a dangerous Mexican drug cartel that has leaked it's way into Southern California. It is at this point that Taylor and Zavala's lives change dramatically and it is the blood and bones of the movie.

"End of Watch" is a new kind of buddy movie and in it, you discover the love and bond that officers in the field have and form for each other. Dealing with extremely dangerous situations is just another day on the job. "End of Watch" is a great film, as was "Training Day". Both movies showed a grit and realism that took it above the typical buddy cop, crime movie. There's no faking the bond these two officers feel for each other. The creator's flesh out every corner of the lives these guys lead right in front of your eyes with skillful camera use and skillful story telling.

Everyone seems to want to be a Youtube one-hit wonder nowadays, something that "End of Watch" laughs at relentlessly.  We see the joke right away, but soon we think the joke's on us; because the cinematography is a blend of video footage and camera close-ups "End of Watch" is a dizzying ride.  It's such a fast and furious ride that it doesn't occur to us that there's no plot and it feels like a lot longer ride than it actually is.  The minimalist plot is also formulaic and entirely predictable.

But I still highly recommend this film.  It's a film by the director of "Training Day," which I liked very much for its attitude and its grit.  "End of Watch" is "Training Day" on steroids.

If  you ever wanted to know what it was like to be a beat cop in L. A. without the danger, this David Ayer film may be as close as you'll get.  Shot in the overused "found footage" style, we get a tension filled action drama with excellent character development and sense of realism.  Jake Gyllenhaal and Michael Pena give memorable performances as partners who are also best friends and confidants, each inviting the other into their extended families.

Officers Taylor (Gyllenhaal) and Zavala (Pena) are hot shot cops who want to do more than make traffic arrests while patrolling a mixed gang section of L. A.  Sometimes heroic (rescuing children from a burning house or from an abusive home) and sometimes foolish (not waiting for backup) they manage to stumble upon an arm of a Mexican cartel involved in human trafficking.  Taylor is filming everything as a project for a class he is taking at a local college.  In addition to using a small traditional HD camera, he attaches mini cameras to himself and his partner.  The squad car is also enhanced with an inward focused camera in addition to the normal outbound dash-cam.

This works most of the time.  The trick works best when it captures the two cops in their car talking to each other.  We get a real sense of their camaraderie and brotherly love for each other.  It also works well when they enter homes and buildings.  When we only get to see what they are seeing, there is a true sense of dread and concern.  The effect doesn't always work however.  Doesn't it seem a bit unusual to see a co-ed cluster of gang-bangers also shooting footage?  For what, their trial?  In the most flagrant use of the home video, who is taking those midrange shots of the cops while they chit chat in a convenience store?  "End of Watch" is a solid, exciting, gut wrenching cop drama and is certainly worth seeing although you may feel a bit dizzy when it's all over.

This intriguing story takes place in the rough-tough streets of L.A., which isn't much different than the streets of New York City. This police drama is about the lives of two young police officers, on-and-off the streets of danger and crime. We follow Brian and Mike as the calls come in to the scenes of different situations. We are introduced to the risk good-clean police-officers must face on an everyday basis, the close encounters to putting their lives on the line, and how easy it is for them to become a victim. The viewer follows the calls to constant danger, regardless of the reason. It could be drugs, or any number of violent-evil scenes in which the two officers must also protect each other. The theme is the value of friendship, a bond between the officer and his partner, and the inside scenes of what type of life they live and how it could affect personal lives. The acting is Excellent, the drama is intriguing, special effects are good, and the story grabs your attention. I didn't expect such good results, but it was very Entertaining and Enjoyable. Highly Recommended to mystery and thriller lovers, who are interested in drama with explosive action!

Directed by David Ayer, "End of Watch" is a police drama that celebrates the value of friendship and the all too frequently unsung efforts of police officers to try to keep the rest of us free from the violence and evil the officers constantly endure.  The movie is set on a rough police beat in South Central Los Angeles and follows the activities of two young officers, Brian Taylor (Jake Gyllenhall) and Mike Zavala (Michael Pena) as they cruise the streets and fight crime. Some scenes of the movie take place in the police academy or the stationhouse and show the cameraderie among the men and the women in uniform.

The movie is a mix of introspection and action. Brian and Mike depend upon each other for their lives, and they are fast friends. As they drive the streets they discuss their families, their respective ethnicities and backgrounds, their dreams and their women. Mike has been married to his high school sweetheart for eight years, while Brian has found a new romantic interest that develops in the course of the movie.  The two men are close in a macho sort of way.

When not in their car, the movie depicts the life of violence and risk in the day-to-day world of the police in a crime-ridden area.  The movie shows a variety of calls, some serious some not, as Brian and Mike look for missing kids, investigate drugs in a sleazy bar, engage in fisticuffs with a small-time crook, rescue small children from a burning home, and much more. Not all the the situations are made clear.  As the movie develops, the action revolves around a large Mexican drug cartel that has its grip on the South Central LA Beat. Brian and Mike are drawn progressively deeper into investigating this cartel with scenes of human trafficking, among other things, leading to a escalating violent close.

The movie captures grungy streets, shabby businesses, and derelict homes as well as a life of constant danger for the officers. One of the officers shoots videos of the passing scenery from the patrol car, giving much of the film a wavery feel to match the actions on the dangerous streets. The musical score of the film is loud, tension building, and pulsating.

The dialogue, from both the police and the criminals, is raw and fully profane. The police in this movie are honest, dedicated to their calling, and willing to assume the frightening risks they take every day. They are tough individuals, both the men and the women, and not saints. Particularly as the violent cartel figures come to prominence towards the end, the movie is effective as an action drama. The stronger theme of the movie, however, lies in its development of the friendship between the two major characters. During a time when the services and characters of the police are not always honored, this movie offers a portrayal of the grittily heroic qualities of the police and their work.

Robin Friedman

I saw the trailer on several occasions in recent weeks when going to other movies in the theatre and I really liked what I saw  and couldn't wait to see this movie. I would not be disappointed.

"End of Watch" (2012 release; 108 min.) brings the story of two LAPD officers, Taylor (played by Jake Gyllenhaal) and Zavala (played by Michael Pena), as they go about their daily beats in LA's Southland. Sometimes the tasks are tedious,  other times the tasks are gruesome and/or scary. Unbeknownst to Taylor and Zavala, they are stumbling into the workings of a Mexican drug cartel, thereby becoming the hunted themselves. To give away more of the plot would ruin your viewing experience, you'll have to see for yourself how it all plays out.

Several comments: first, be aware that the movie is mostly shot in the style of  the TV shows "Cops", so if you have a hard time viewing hand-held camera photography, you'll probably want to sit this one out. Second, it appears that writer/director David "Training Day" Ayer is completely at home in the world of cop dramas; the movie feels as authentic as you've ever seen a cop movie, and in that vein it feels similar to "training Day". Third, this is as much a "buddy" movie than it is a cop drama, and the interaction between Gyllenhaal and Pena really carries the movie. Last, not surprisingly, the acting is mostly superb; besides the lead actors, check out also Anna "Up In the Air" Kendrick in a small but noticeable role as Taylor's girlfriend/eventual wife. Bottom line: this is one tough, gritty cop drama. Not for the faint of heart, but otherwise highly recommended!
gritty little tale of 2 cops in a car. The actors do a great job The story is ok. Enough reality to get by some tear inducing melodrama.

It seems like David Ayer has been making the same film over and over again since "Training Day," doesn't it? While he didn't direct "Training Day," every film he's directed since then has revolved around South Central and/or the LAPD. The intriguing aspect though is that Ayer tweaks a few things here and there to make whatever is his most recent film a bit stronger and a bit better than his previous works despite being similar in story and execution. "End of Watch" is certainly his strongest effort, but comes up short when it tries to jump into superb territory.

Two LAPD police officers, Brian Taylor (Jake Gyllenhaal) and Mike Zavala (Michael Pena), are partners and best friends. They're put on the fast track to success after they handle a car chase that ends in shots being fired completely by the book. Despite their constant joking and the way they kind of strut around the precinct, their job is extremely dangerous and everyone around them does their best to remind them of that. A routine stakeout turns out to be so much more when they find a pot of soup filled with stacks of cash along with a bejewelled pistol and a golden AK-47. The Mexican cartel are in Los Angeles and Brian and Mike have to watch where they step before they bite off more than they can chew.

"End of Watch" is filmed almost entirely in that handheld and almost documentary type of camera perspective. Gyllenhaal and Pena wear cameras on their pockets the entire time while Gyllenhaal carries around a camera. It isn't quite as shaky or as bad as you may think, but it's basically a slightly more HD step above what you'd see on "Cops." Considering the content of the film, it actually feels like it's throwing you right into the action which is more than likely the intent of the style. But it may still give you motion sickness if you've had issues with it in the past.

The chemistry between Gyllenhaal and Pena carries the film; their constant ribbing of one another and the way they confide in one another really makes it seem like their bond runs deep. Their friendship is built to pull you in for something that happens later on and even though you sense that coming a mile away the event still hits you like a bag of bricks when it finally does happen.

It almost seems like "End of Watch" starts off very lighthearted and slowly snowballs into something darker and grittier before completely pulling the rug out from underneath you in its final moments. It begins with Brian and Mike constantly joking around and each call they have gets more and more serious. They're dealing with gang wars, but they spend their down time discussing the type of women they want to be with or telling ridiculous stories. Then they get the call to find the missing children, follow the lead on the guy that pulls a gun out on Mike after they pull him over, offer assistance to Van Hauser (David Harbour) and his partner, and eventually get baited into following that van that runs a red light. It's a shame we didn't get to see more of the shotgun cam perspective as it's incredibly effective and pretty awesome.

"End of Watch" contains a lot more moments that take your breath away or attempt to shock you than Ayer's other works. The scene with the house that's on fire is incredibly difficult to watch as is the Van Hauser rescue and the minivan tail. The film seems to chicken out at the end though. It has you in the palm of its hand and is all set to end on a really disheartening note, but then backtracks and has you laughing as you exit the theater. It makes sense as most people want to leave a film on a high note, but speaking as someone who thrives on edgier filmmaking and depressing conclusions the action drama kind of loses its nerve at the last minute and goes with something light and fluffy instead of something heavy and contemplative.

"End of Watch" pushes boundaries, is extremely gritty, and has this sense of realism that isn't usually found in films like this. The chemistry between Jake Gyllenhaal and Michael Pena is also incredibly strong, but the film almost seems to lose its testicles in its closing moments. It spends all this time showing you edgy content and pushing you towards the edge of your seat and then just kind of delivers this lukewarm conclusion even though it had all of the elements of leaving you with something great. Something that may get overlooked that you should keep an eye out for is Frank Grillo's performance. He has so little screen time, but has one scene with a huge amount of emotional impact.

"End of Watch" is an impressive action drama and easily David Ayer's most impressive film to date, but just loses its momentum in its final act to keep it from being really, really good.

First of all, let me say that I am not a professional movie critic. So, I am just going to evaluate the movie based on my personal experience and enjoyability of the film. This film was phenomenal. It was very well directed. The plot was very credible and for those working on law enforcement, it will seem too accurate. The actors nailed it. It was also filmed like "Cloverfield", to make you believe that you are part of the action as a first person viewer. That was my only complaint. Since, this type of filming seems to give me headaches.  Overall, I would give this film 5 stars based on the following: enjoyability, credibility, acting, costumes/clothing, special effects and plot delivery/transition and conclusion. This is not your typical "happy ending" cop movie. So, if you want a happy ending fake cop movie, do not bother watching this one. Great movie, overall. Very well portrayed.

I really enjoyed this movie.  it was filled with action, drama, sadness and some hilarious scenes.  Underneath, there is a window into the challenging lives of patrol officers in south-central LA.  They put up with a lot of crap from the public, there are plenty of big-headed egos, and tons of grit and toughness.  At the same time this movie shows that these officers are also human -- dealing with life's typical struggles like relationship issues, family health, and financial struggles, all while watching drug dealers and street gangs/thugs get flush with cash as they grow their wealth illegally.  There are several scenes where you know one of these guys needs to cross the line by pocketing a few hundred or thousand bucks that no one will miss.  There's also some great interplay between Michael Pena and Jake G.

There is plenty of foul language, gun fights, blood, death, etc. so its not a good movie for kids, but young adults and older will do just fine unless they cannot deal with those issues.

I wanted to see this film for a long time.  Having watched it tonight, I am incredibly disappointed.  First, if you have vertigo, or any kind of seizure disorder, don't watch this film.  Gyllenhaal's character is filming their life as cops as a film project, and the camera work is all over the map.  Up, down, in, out, from his belt buckle up to his face  --  it's incredibly distracting, and completely unnecessary.

As for the story underneath the horrid camera work is below average.  We've all seen buddy cop films, and this one is not a standout.  The men were not interesting, and the dialogue between them was "bro, dude," etc,. and the subject matter was women, marriage, sex, police work.  Absolutely nothing of substance.

As for what they "stumbled onto," as they tell you in the description, is nothing more than you'd see in 100 episodes of Law & Order: SVU, but for these guys, for some reason, the bad guys wanted them.  I will say no more than that, but to me it made no real sense.

The patrolling part of the work, and the people they encountered was interesting, and the performances were good.  Unfortunately, they were two characters I didn't care much about.  They were pretty juvenile, and one-dimensional.

Save your time and money and watch Training Day or something.

What started out as a great drama turned into a farce. The first half to a third of this movie was stellar. Great writing, great scripting and a great concept. The chemistry these two actors had with one another was incredible! This was an atypical "buddy cop" movie. Nevertheless it did have its flaws--some minor and some serious.

No cop would ever put his gun belt down to fight a perp. An LAPD cop as we've seen from the perfidy of Laurence Powell, Timothy Wind, Stacey Coon and Theodore Briseno will bash someone's brain in and/or shoot someone (Armed Or Unarmed) and ask questions later. That was a minor flaw. Another flaw comes when one cop says to another--"you're not a detective." But the cop continues on a hunch without reporting to his supervisors. This would have garnered them a serious reprimand if not a suspension.

The most ludicrous thing in the movie was four gang members having the cops in their sights from an elevated vantage point and opening up with four or five AK-47's and MISSING IN FULL AUTOMATIC! NO WAY! The credibility of the movie went out the window with that. There's a reason why Dr. Harry Turtledove chose the AK-47 as his rifle of choice for the Confederate Army in his fictitious Guns of the South book. The weapon is the single best rifle ever to be created! It is accurate and in full automatic can cut down scores of charging men. Those cops would have been swish cheese cops and anyone with military training can verify that fact. It's accurate even in select fire. See the scene from the movie Boyz N the Hood to see the accuracy of this weapon as it cuts down four (Not Two) men running away.

Intense. Is the best word that comes to mind. The Blue Line of men and women that stand between right and wrong , good and bad is what enables us to sleep at night. I have had to deal with those who raise their middle finger to the law and spit in your face. So yes I can relate to this story. Our law officers are not superman or wonderman. No these are people just like you and me, choosing to do a job not many want. They laugh, they cry, they bleed and have other life problems as all do. In other words their human. Doing a dirty job in a tough world so all may live their lives.

Not an incredibly well known or blockbuster type movie, but good nonetheless. Very intense, great action and an underrated crime drama.

Cinematography: Was not what I was expecting. Upon reading the synopses on IMDB, saying that the film was shot in a documentary style, I was expecting a "found footage" film. Something that was going to be very shaky and annoying. Rather, I was pleasantly surprised. Although there were shots in the film that were very shaky and they were not annoying. It was mostly because it felt like I was actually watching something that could have been filmed with a handheld camcorder; with film grain, soft focus, and the occasional shake from walking or driving, all in all, it was well done.

Audio: Just as with the visuals, the audio would change according to the scene/shot to make it really feel as if it was coming through a camcorder. There wasn't a point in time during the film that I could remember where the audio didn't sound good. It wasn't absolutely perfect, but it was done very well.

Music: From was I can remember, the music fit the film but it wasn't memorable. I can't say all the much about the music since I cannot really remember it.

Editing: I loved the editing. The less you notice the editing, the better the editor did his/her job. Which I why I tend to pay close attention to the editing. This film was cut very smoothly. Each shot was held for the perfect about of time. I saw no jarring cuts. There were some jump cuts, but they were used quite well. In fact, the film was edited so nicely that from time to time, I didn't notice the cuts. Although the editing of the film was no Memento, it was still beautifully pieced together.

Story/plot: I felt that there was no real plot. It basically was just the lives of two cops and the stuff they dealt with. Other then that, there wasn't much too it. When they brought back a character that was established early on in the film, I wasn't really expecting it as I didn't believe that there was much significance to that character. Basically, I wasn't the biggest fan of the concept. But the execution was well done.

By now, everyone knows that I hate these camcorder films, because they are lazy and don't really have much of a story to them, but there is an exception to that rule, and that is the TV show Cops. Police work comes with natural real life drama and action, in this instance the script really does write itself, so I was okay with it being used for a film like this. I just wish it had been done more naturally. I understand that the film takes place in a gang infested area of L.A. and that they needed to make it more dramatic and action packed for it to succeed in theaters, but you talk about going over the top. That's where Director, David Ayer comes in, after all gangs and going over the top are his specialty. End of Watch does have some great chase scenes and some really cool moments between partners, but for the most part it's just one non-stop explosion filled gun battle after another, making Los Angeles look like Fallujah. The point of view cameras do give us an interesting look at the action and some new perspective into how it's all made, which I thought was really cool, but I mean the lack of story line and constant shooting was beyond ridiculous. I'm some what surprised they'd didn't just go full on crazy and release the whole thing in 3-D.

3 1/2 stars -- There's nothing at all wrong with the performances here -- Jake Gyllenhaal and Michael Pena are two cops who together patrol a very rough section of Los Angeles, Anna Kendrick and Natalie Martinez play their respective wives. It's a conceit of the movie that Brian Taylor (Gyllenhaal) is filming as much as he can of his life as a cop, although his precinct captain isn't ecstatic about that.  But even when he isn't deliberately filming, there are body cams, surveillance cams (for some very nasty bad guys), and car-interior dash cams -- and all of the video thus generated ostensibly makes up what we see of their lives on the screen.  The idea is to seem to show us, the viewer, an unfiltered view of the cops' lives, so the angles are odd, the visual quality is grainy at times, and the pace is hectic.  Of course, the impression that this is all unfiltered is an illusion -- the director, David Ayer, has cut and shaped this pseudo-documentary material for his purposes, and these purpose seem to be to create a sense of tension and breathlessness as the cops go about their business.  Such editing creates a sense of imminent threat in many situations (the kinds of cameras ostensibly used here can see only so much, after all), and as we watch we are certainly caught up in the action in a way that we wouldn't be with more conventional pacing and filming.  In a way, then, the movie is a triumph of style -- call it pseudo-documentary style -- and that style works to a certain extent.

There are limits, though.  The characters and the plot and the situations are standard-issue crime drama: it's just the look that's different.  The cops are sympathetic characters: courageous, honest, protective of one another, tough, sensitive.  Their lives haven't hardened them, and as family men, they are exemplary.  In a more conventionally-paced story, they might strike us as sentimentally idealized, but such is the pace here, that that doesn't strike us until later, when we're thinking over what we've seen.  Without giving away too much of the plot, I can say that, in the course of doing their job, they run up against the Sinaloa drug cartel, that also seems to run a human trafficking operation.  They soon learn that Federal officials have that group under surveillance, and that leads to some awkward moments -- the Feds want to make their moves in their own time, and Taylor and Zavala (Pena) feel compelled to take action when they feel people's lives are in danger, no matter what the Fed agenda is.  Their interference, of course, is something that the cartel becomes aware of, and there's a set-up for a final confrontation.  All of these kinds of plot complications are what I mean by "standard-issue crime drama," but credit where credit is due -- we see them through new eyes, as it were.

At bottom, though, it's a buddy-movie.  Both the cops are very likeable, and for all the profane chatter of the dialogue, the movie is sentimental.  If we grant Ayer his visual and editing choice and are thus susceptible to their expressive effects, you have to admit that the movie is well put-together.  Ayer's only serious misjudgement, I think, is the final scene -- a conversation in the police car.  Even so, I can imagine some viewers thinking that it works.

Great movie. This is one of those films that you don't hear about at first but it builds through word of mouth. I happened to come across it on Netflix originally and loved it. I recently did the Amazon Instant video to see it again. The pairing of Michael Pena and Jake Gyllenhaal makes this a great film. They have a great chemistry together and also with the other characters like the cop played by America Ferrara.

It gives you a new respect for what the police, especially the LAPD, are out there doing every day in some of the worst neighborhoods, especially South Central. I had no idea because you don't really hear about this on the news, or if you do, it's just about an isolated incident. It's presented like a documentary because Jake Gyllenhaal's character is actually filming for a college class he's taking in his pre-law program.

Very well done film and a story nobody has done before, at least not like this. I highly recommend it.

This LA cop film is unusual in several ways. First of all: the cops are the good guys. Then: most of the action is filmed by hand held cameras, which I don't normally like much, but which works very well here. Then: Jake G's lead character is filming much of it, and commenting it, almost like reality TV. This takes us into the events more effectively than I would have expected.
The story: two uniformed cops in their car, bantering and joking when nothing goes on, good friends in private life, much challenged by darkness when calls come. They are an effective and honest team and they believe in their mission. They attract the wrath of a particularly vicious bunch of gangsters, which leads into bloody murder. Profanity levels are substantial and impressive. Soon experts will be able to use nothing but the f-word and will still be understood... After all, life is simple and the f-word says it all. Right?

Whats it about?

Brian Taylor (Jake Gyllenhaal) and Mike Zavala (Michael Pena) are two L.A. police officers and long-time friends who go all Riggs and Murtaugh on a Mexican drug cartel and end up with a price on their heads.

What did I think?

Look, I guess this movie has its positives, especially if you're already a fan of cop films. But their big thing at the start is how this is all footage shot by the cops themselves, and then its like the director just straight-up forgot thats what they were doing, or maybe he just thought it was too hard to maintain. Handheld/"found" footage is a slippery beast at the best of times, but establishing it as the crux of your storytelling method then just periodically abandoning it seems kind of insane, really.

Recommended by an  LAPD friend who used to work South Central. it's very well done. The critics' reviews are pretty much on point. I knocked off a star for two reasons. First, I didn't think the combination of 'found footage' and conventional cinematography worked very well together. And second, I did not care for the sound mixing at all. Sound levels were inconsistent, and I found myself almost constantly adjusting the volume of my sound system up during quiet segments, then back down when the music soundtrack kicked in. Still, I recommend the movie--my LAPD friend says its about as realistic a view of cop life as you're going to see.

I was very favourably surprised and even more, IMPRESSED, by this 2012 thriller drama. It is definitely one of the best crime films I saw in those last years. Below, more of my impressions, with some limited SPOILERS.

The film tells the story of two veteran LAPD officers, Brian Taylor (Jake Gyllenhaal) and Miguel Zavala (Michael Pena). They are simple uniformed street patrol officers, albeit Taylor, a former Marine, wants to make detective and studies in the evenings. As part of his studies he records a lot of what happens on their patrols. This film is composed integrally with recordings, mostly those made by Taylor, but also a couple of news reportings, some official ceremonial recordings and also some footage of conversations of street gangsters, moslty made with their cell phones.

I will not say much about the story because it contains twists, surprises and developments which should be discovered integrally by the viewers. I would really advise AGAINST researching this film on internet before viewing, because here any kind of spoilers damage the viewing experience quite seriously. Suffice it to say that Taylor and Zavala are tough (and extremely potty mouthed) but honest and quite likeable police officers, who patrol a particularly rotten, dangerous part of Los Angeles.

Well known by local street gangs for being courageous, tough (and dangeorus if needs be) but fair and honest, they are treated with a (very) reluctant respect by some of gangbangers - but also supremely hated by many others. Amongst the latter the most prominent is Big Evil (Maurice Compte), a (not very sane) leader of a paricularly vicious Latino outfit, the Curbside Gang.

With time we also come to know Miguel's wife Gabby (Natalie Martinez) and Taylor's most recent girlfriend (Anna Kendrick), as well as some other police officers and brass both men are working with.

Before "End of watch" David Ayers made two other "cops+gangsters in LA" films, "Harsh Times" in 2006 with Christian Bale and "Street Kings" in 2008 with Keeanu Reeves. The first one was bad and the second one hardly better - in fact I forgot what they were about almost immediately after watching them. But this film, well, this is a whole different enchilada!

"End of watch" is a very good film, both in its technical visual aspect and in its scenario, which is an exceptionally solid thing. Most of this film is dialogs and they are actually very good - even if the amount of OBSCENITIES is such that some DVD players will probably not resist it...))) We are frequently surprised and shocked, but those surprises and shocks actually make sense and the whole story flows very logically and harmoniously until the end. It is a thing rare enough in recent films to deserve particular praise.

The treasures in this film are many and you deserve to discover them by yourself, but I simply must state here, that whoever invented the character of La La (Yakira Flakiss Garcia) should get an Oscar. The very idea of naming the very lesbian and absolutely TERRIFYING top killer of Curbside Gang after one of Teletubbies, well, I bow very low to whomever thought about it...)))

As written in the title of this review, for my personal taste, if "The Shield" was a movie instead of TV show and about good cops, instead of rotten evil ones, well, it would be this film... And for me it is the SUPREME praise, as I simply ADORED "The Shield".

The two leads are terrific in a tale that makes patrolling in South Central look only slightly less dangerous than the streets of Fallujah in 2005.  Gyllenhaal and Pena have an easy rapport in their scenes in their black-and-white that's a mark of good acting and direction.  Without giving anything away, the next to last scene is cribbed from LA Confidential.  There's also a scene, which I'm surprised critics did not remark upon when the film was released, that makes the viewer question the ethics of using very small children in violent films.  But the action will get your adrenaline pumping, and will probably make you glad you're not a cop.

If you're looking for a movie purely about cops, in particular the LAPD, maybe something unique and unexpected, then I think you found your movie.

Yes, the whole handheld video clich is a bit played out and certainly detracts from the overall quality of this flick. Also, about 60 to 70% of this movie is nothing more than characters having boring, meaningless, banal conversations. However, the action scenes make up for the film's downfalls in spades. The action in this movie is crisp, relevant, and tense beyond description. Well worth the time expenditure of watching the film in it's entirely. In fact, I wholeheartedly recommend you fast forward past all the parts where characters are merely talking, and just watch the action!

i usually enjoy cop drama's, S.W.A.T., Bad Boys II, and the latter. But End of Watch just sucked..

My first complaint with the movie, is the overuse of the F bomb. I'm a grown adult male, who can handle and usually not even notice the F word in a movie that is well written, Ex. Reservoir Dogs. But this movie's language borders gets repetetive, and annoying with how much swearing there is.. They CONSTANTLY use the F word to show the writers stupidity and lack of adjectives. It makes watching the movie again a chore..

My second complaint, is there is just too much character development. They show officer Brian Taylor and his new girlfriend dancing, singing, drinking, making out, gossiping, and more. I understand they wanted to make the ending more impacting for the audience that way.. But it goes overboard and feels like filler..

Overall, i'd say pass this. If your curious, Pirate it, but don't pay a cent to see this trash.

End of Watch is about two young Los Angeles police officers who stumble upon secrets of the Mexican drug cartel which leads them to become the cartel's targets. The leading roles are Officer Brian Taylor (Jake Gyllenhaal) and Officer Mike Zavala (Michael Pena), who are partners in the LAPD. The villains of the movie come off as very evil, hateful people. One is even named 'Big Evil' because, well, as he put it, "my evil is big."

Although this film is directed by the same man who did 'Training Day', it is nothing like that movie. This film led by Gyllenhaal and Pena shows qualities, between the two, that every officer should have; those being courage, loyalty, and integrity. There is no dirtiness or crookedness about them like with Denzel Washington in 'Training Day'. They are honorable and dedicated to their job and loyal to one another, you can feel the sense of brotherhood between them. I felt like both actors did exceptionally well and gave a realistic/ natural performance. Prior to seeing this I wasn't a Jake Gyllenhaal fan but he won me over in this performance.

Throughout the movie you'll see them at the barracks, on the job, and off duty within their personal lives in an attempt to make you feel connected with them on a personal level. The majority of the film is shot from a first person perspective which allows you to see things not only from Officer Zavala and Taylor's POV but also the gang members POV. Different ways the film is recorded include cameras attached to each officer's shirt, handheld camcorders, a dash cam etc. I found it interesting but some people will not like this filming style at all.

I'll be completely honest this movie is a tear jerker and it's also one of my all time favorite movies. If you can handle the filming style; you'll laugh, you'll cry and you'll love End of Watch.

This was a really well done movie. I ended up renting it a few times before I decided I would just be better off buying it. Watching "End of Watch," with the humorous banter between LAPD officers Brian Taylor (Jake Gyllenhaal) and Miguel Zavala (Michael Pena) cruising along in their patrol car and responding to dispatch calls on their radio, reminded me of watching episodes of Jack Webb's "Adam-12" TV series with my mother when I was a kid, only full of F-bombs. If any entertainment since "Adam-12" has portrayed the LAPD in such a favorable light as "End of Watch," I'm not aware of it. The film was made with LAPD's full support.

Like on "Adam-12," some of the calls Taylor and Zavala respond to are goofy and some are serious. These tough, courageous men enthusiastically embrace the often difficult, dangerous work of fighting crime and savings lives, while revealing deep bonds with each other and their civilian families. It's fascinating to see their approaches to different situations. We realize that modern police work requires not just courage and strength, but a vast range of interpersonal and law enforcement skills, social work, and judgment.

However, before we are through, "End of Watch" has descended far below the sunny surface of "Adam-12." Taylor and Zavala work South Central LA, where poverty, drugs and vicious gangs have shredded the social fabric. They inadvertently stumble into a rat's nest of human and drug trafficking that's carried out by a Mexican drug cartel and under investigation by federal Immigration and Customs Enforcement.agents. It's gruesome, nasty descent into a crime hell that's not for those with weak stomachs.

"End of Watch" is shot mostly with hand-held cameras, which gives the viewer an "in the action" feel but may bother some people. I watched it on my computer screen so it did not annoy me too much, but had I seen it in a theater, I probably would have felt wobbly. The acting by the two leads is very good. The script carries you effectively into the workaday world of cops on a tough beat. But while you get to know and like Taylor and Zavala, this is accomplished in kind of a lazy way--they're honorable guys who love their families and friends and are fighting the good fight. It might have been more interesting if they had been subject to some moral ambiguity. The other problem with the script for me was the incessant F-bombs. I really don't object to "bad language" in movies if it fits the characters and situations (Joe Pesci in "Goodfellas"? No problem), but if you put an F-bomb in almost every sentence, and sometimes more than one per sentence, it starts to feel like monotonous, lazy writing. I heard that writer-director David Ayer finished the script in six days. A little rewriting might have been a good thing.

I did not love "End of Watch," but I liked it and appreciated the insight into the daily grind of police work it afforded.

This movie seemed like it would be interesting when it came out, I thought the story would be more interesting and possibly more action, instead its more of a cop buddy drama with some comedy thrown in.  The basic plot is Jake Gyllenhaal and Michael Pena are patrol cops worki
ng the east L.A. area, responding to dangerous situations and forming a bond in the process.

End of Watch comes at a time when we the audience have already seen many, many movies with similar themes.  I suppose that when the producers were making this movie, they thought, we'll make a cop film that doesn't have corruption and just shows them trying to do job.  While I get the concept, the movie consistently felt lacking.  Where I thought there would be suspense and action, instead there's routine scenes of them following/interacting with dangerous gang members, as part of an investigation THEY AREN'T EVEN SUPPOSED TO BE DOING IN THE FIRST PLACE.  They are not corrupt, but they definitely overstep their boundaries.

The details of the criminals they're after aren't important, but there's a murder in the movie, both characters find the body report it, but take it further.  They decide to investigate themselves and go find the killers, something left to detectives.  There's one scene where they are hanging out at the house the person was killed it and a superior more or less warns both of them to stay away and don't take it further; of course they are good to not abuse their power and track down the killer themselves.

I could only wonder what actual police officers think of this movie.  There's probably some movies that they think are absolutely ridiculous in their premise or the character's actions, but this movie probably has to be one of the of the worst offenders.  Early on Gyllenhall's character carries around a digital video camera around with him, filming other officers and the crime scenes they arrive on; everyone is annoyed with it, but he more or less carries on with this behavior.  I don't believe there's any universe where this scenario would take place.  Gyllenhall plays a wise-ass eager young cop, somebody who is loyal to force, but questions it in a way a slacker-civilian would.  Again, watch the movie and you'll agree with me that the other cops would have beat the s*** out of him for most of his antics on the film.

Michael Pena's character is more of the 'straight' man to Gyllenhall's comic-relief.  Again though, you think that there will be something different or unique to these characters or story, but not really, they're relationship is copied from Mel Gibson and Danny Glover in Lethal Weapon.  The conversations in the car boil down due their differences in marriage and relationships.  Michael Pena's character is married, Gyllenhall is not, and he gives Gyllenhall an interesting piece of advice, "you're the smartest guy I know, you'll never find the perfect one, just find one thats down to cook for you."  Thoughtful advice, although it at times feels like I'm watch a tv movie.

I gave this me 2 stars because its somewhat entertaining, but not too involving.  There's a scene where the cops are having a morning meeting to talk about writing tickets and you get the sense that at times their job is as useful as a meter maid and the movie at times wants to explore that idea, but it never really goes in that direction.  Instead what were treated to is typical formulaic police drama, without all the excitement.  At one point I thought the two main characters were going to high five.
Having lived in LA for many years, it was very cool to see familiar areas of the city in this movie, not to mention this is the very type of crime that goes down in the City of Angels.

Overall, this was a very good and different movie. Some people may not like it because of the way it's shot, and how they tell the story (it is very different in both those areas).  But I really liked it because of those differences.
The story follow two partners, and best friends, of the LAPD who work Central Los Angeles together, as they go through their daily lives, both on the job and off. Reminded me a little of the movie "Colors" with Sean Penn, but this was a much better story, in my opinion.
Good strong story, great characters, excellent casting, good action scenes, some heartfelt moments too, and some really funny and honest dialogue.  Also, the movie is shot in combat camera style, so it's very fluid which I think adds another dimension to the unfolding of the story (that would not be there if it was shot with a regular camera). Props to the editor too, because it's a lot harder to cut a movie like this, I'm sure.  I got sucked right in, in the first three minutes of the opening (which is quite unusual for a movie to have a dramatic opening), and became invested in the two main characters to the point where I wanted to know what was going to happen, and was rooting for them the whole way.
I would purchase this for my collection, and would watch it again.

David Ayers is a big stud.  Seriously.  You can tell he cares about diving deep into Cop culture.  And he's not afraid to give big props to their (obvious) merit.  But it's never saccharin or sickly-sweet sentimentality.  It's gritty.  Raw.  Intense.  The two leads gave bravura performances... seemingly living the role, not just acting it.
Quite simply, this is the BEST movie ever made that captures what the police sub-culture is truly like.  Acting is fantastic.

"To Protect and Serve".  I remember as a kid when I watched repeats of "Adam-12" and "Dragnet" that phrase emblazoned on the patrol cars of L.A.'s finest.  That motto was given new resonance years later in Dennis Hopper's underrated "Colors".  I didn't think anything new could be added to the cop movie drama and for the most part director-writer David Ayer succeeds in infusing a time tested genre with something fresh.  He does so by employing documentary style techniques such as hand held cameras that make you feel like you are in the car with real police officers.  For instance you think you are following the daily grind of Officer Brian Taylor and his partner Miguel Zavala instead of actors Jake Gyllenhaal and Michael Pena.  Some have taken issue with the profane exchanges between the two which give  new definition to the term L.A.P.D. Blue and admittedly I found a tad excessive.  People curse Mr. Ayer.  We get the point.  Also, I thought the main subplot of a Mexican drug cartel putting a contract on the two a bit farfetched.  The plot strand results in an ending that I could have predicted before the film even started.  On the whole this is a fine film if profanity and violence are not an issue with you.

Written and directed by David Ayer, writer of "Training Day," "End of Watch" chronicles the daily activities of LA police officers Brian Taylor (Jake Gyllenhaal) and Mike Zavala (Michael Pea). Shot in South Central, Los Angeles (where the director grew up as a teenager), the film benefits from the documentary-style realism of the location shooting, but what makes "End of Watch" special is the powerhouse acting from the leads and a strong sense of camaraderie that develops between the characters.

The plotline of "End of Watch" looks episodic at first sight, with subplots about Brian's girlfriend Janet (Anna Kendrick) and Mike's pregnant wife Gabby (Natalie Martinez). You may wonder where the entire film is going, but keep watching and you will realize there is one uneasy undercurrent that erupts in the final chapter, presence of a new power (represented by AK-47) that is far more dangerous than the local gangsters.

A variety of video sources including a dashboard camera of the police cruiser is used here to present the lives of the officers realistically. The "mocumentary" style that is overused these days is employed effectively, enhancing the gritty touch of the film without disrupting the narrative flow.

The film's unique visual style is not for everyone, but "End of Watch" is a fine cop drama worth watching for the strong performances from the leads.

Fans that enjoy movies starring the  "f" word  will definitely "thumbs up" this production.  Billed as a "powerful cop movie", End of Watch is anything but.  The plot consists of  nothing more than ongoing contests between the characters to shout their most creative- albeit vulgar - use of the "f" word.  Produced in the style of a backyard homemade movie,  even the quality of filming is an offense and an assault on the eyes -  one a serious amateur filmmaker would hardly lay claim to.  Verbal pollutants are often used when there is a serious absence of story, and End of Watch  is no exception.  Some viewers, however, are entertained by such and not offended when actors make millions  for just shooting off their mouths.  Actor Jake Gyllenhaal is a great assist in the film's receiving a "R" - for "raunchy" rating.  True fans of crime drama or law enforcement flicks with real entertainment value,  would more than likely retitle this movie, "Unwatchable".

Amidst a sea of cop films, cop-buddy films, and LA cop films, this movie truly stands out.  It impresses on every level: great writing, excellent acting, superb direction.  It has wit, heart, grit, and much suspense. It IS quite violent, but never gratuitously.  Above all, the relationship between the two leads has such an easy, believable flow to it. You really feel like you want to hang with these guys.  Their scenes together are quite verbose, but never in a forced way.  To me this film is up
there on a par with "The Shield" and "The Wire", two of my all-time favorite series.  (Oh, great soundtrack too......)

Aaaaargh!  Oh, my Lawd, what an awful 22 minutes I spent grimacing through this loud, rap-infested piece of trash passing itself off as a movie.  Just the trailer told me I didn't want to see this movie, but I was entertaining company who chose it.  Well, after less than half-an-hour, I just had to tell my guest "enough is too much" and shut it off.  If I could give less than a star, believe me, this would be a negative 37.  Brightly shot, with jerky camera motions and angles supposed to be documentary (the premise is one of the cops is shooting the movie using button cameras and small hand-held cameras, for a school project), the acting is hammy, the premise waaaaay out there and the setting simply a place you do not want to go.  There was more black gang trash talk (read "muthaf***er") in the first three minutes than I have heard in my entire rowdy life, including four visits to NFL locker rooms at half-time, a KKK meeting in Mississippi  and a gay rodeo.  Sheesh.

Save yourself.  Put your money away.  Avert your eyes, cover your ears, breath through your mouth, take your finger away from the "buy now" button and hie thee to a much better move.  Like "Ishtar" for example.  Any crippled dog would be better than this crap.  Don't say I didn't sternly warn you.  Now I'm going to wash out my ears and poke my eyes out......

Every decade or so we get treated to a cop film so gritty and hard-core it leaves an indelible mark on our pop culture consciousness. In the 1970s it was The French Connection. In the '80s, Colors. In the '90s, L.A. Confidential. In the early oughts, Training Day (I guess Hot Fuzz (Widescreen Edition) doesn't count, huh?). Heck, you can even go as far back as the 1940s and my pick would be Akira Kurosawa's Stray Dog (The Criterion Collection). In the 2010s it's this one. Today the barbershop chatter revolved around the best cinematic pairing of 2013, and I had a horse in the race. In END OF WATCH Jake Gyllenhaal and Michael Pea burrow into the skins of their characters so impressively, their characters present a friendship that feels so natural and vibes so organically, it punches you in the gut to watch the harrowing stuff they go thru deep into the film. END OF WATCH comes with bells and whistles. Writer/director David Ayer, whose dramatis personae habitually haunt L.A.'s grimy underbelly, flirts with the conceit of the found footage film but doesn't stay faithful to it. Still, there's a sense of immediacy whenever we're getting those first person perspectives, via assorted surveillance cameras, dash cams, cell phone cams, and those tiny Scorpion cameras the police pin on their uniform to record incidents. Ayer maintains a firm command of tone and pace, stringing you along and stringing you along and then sometimes pulling the rug out from under you. The film observes the daily grind of two LAPD patrol officers and partners, Brian Taylor (Jake Gyllenhaal) and Mike Zavala (Michael Pea), as they try to keep the peace in South Central Los Angeles. The trailer fools you into thinking this is a straight-up, ba11s-to-the-wall cop thriller, but you got played. Yep, there are moments of abrupt violence sprinkled in when Taylor and Zavala spring into action, but there isn't a sustained thru arc in which they're on the run from the Mexican drug cartel. Mostly, END OF WATCH unfolds in leisurely, episodic fashion, with Taylor and Zavala responding to calls ranging from the mundane to the ridiculous to situations that occasionally do end up going sideways. Gracing the film are these character-building intervals that lend texture and depth and give us a peek into what's relevant in their personal lives (Anna Kendrick and Natalie Martinez are marvelous as their respective love interests). What the trailer also doesn't disclose is how funny the movie is. Gyllenhaal and Pea muster up an incredible chemistry. Much of the humor stems from their naturalistic dialogue, "naturalistic" maybe because much of it was ad-libbed between them. The off-the-cuff patter, the smooth rhythms of their interplay provide many of the high points. It's almost impossible not to care for these guys. And when they get so successful with their street busts in "Shootin' Newton" that, in the third act, the Mexican drug cartel has no choice but to put a bounty on them, by then, you are firmly invested and very concerned and biting your nails. This deserves to be seen. It is visceral. It is moving. It is a slice of life. It puts you behind the scenes and in the front line with L.A.'s finest. END OF WATCH is one of those rare cop movies that doesn't exploit the badge but genuinely honors it. I was so taken by Gyllenhaal's opening voiceover monologue, I had to write it down. Boy, that was a lot of rewinding and playing back on the DVD, but worth it: "I am the police, and I'm here to arrest you. You've broken the law. I did not write the law. I may disagree with the law but I will enforce it. No matter how you plead, cajole, beg or attempt to stir my sympathy. Nothing you do will stop me from placing you in a steel cage with gray bars. If you run away I will chase you. If you fight me I will fight back. If you shoot at me I will shoot back. By law I am unable to walk away. I am a consequence. I am the unpaid bill. I am fate with a badge and a gun. Behind my badge is a heart like yours. I bleed, I think, I love, and yes I can be killed. And although I am but one man, I have thousands of brothers and sisters who are the same as me. They will lay down their lives for me and I them. We stand watch together. The thin-blue-line, protecting the prey from the predators, the good from the bad. We are the police." The DVD's bonus stuff: - Audio Commentary with writer/director David Ayer - 17 Deleted Scenes (totaling 00:46:22 minutes, including an alternate ending) - "Fate with a Badge" (00:02:10 minutes) - "In the Streets" (00:02:11) - "Women on Watch" (00:02:01) - "Watch Your Six" (00:02:36) - "Honors" (00:02:06)

Let me start out by saying in words what the four stars illustrate: I GENERALLY LIKED THIS FILM !!!!

A commitment was made to use-- and perhaps it might even be fair to say OVERUSE-- the hand-held camera technique to give the film an edgy quality . . . yes, that's obviously true.  More to the point, however, it populated it's star roles with what seemed the enactment of truly believable personalities.  And, that these characters were doomed from the beginning, this did not emerge suddenly and irrevocably, but rather slowly and in a way calculated to get you to forget about it even after you were plainly warned to expect that.

Having done street gang work myself, I was never able to forget about it at any time I was out there, because under those circumstances, if someone suggests to you JUST ONCE that you have somehow stepped into a special hair-trigger gun site, you never forget about it.  In that setting, it is just too easy to get blown away.  From that point of view, the film's effort to get you to forget about it did at times border on the silly.  Even at the end, for the Hispanic cop to get so wrapped up in the injuries to his partner that his back was an open invitation for the shooters to appear can only be naivite about working the mean streets in the course of a shootout.  No good war movie would suggest that hero figures get lost in fallen comrades in the middle of a firefight action; that occurs later, after the shooting stops and the enemy's whereabouts are accounted for.  But our guy stopped to weep while he was on the run.  It's in spots like that that the film started to get puzzling for me.  Were they willing to fracture reality to tell us how sad the guy was?  Also remember that this is the same guy who held his gun against the inside of the door of his car (out of sight) when he was talking to the Black gang member who was trying to repay him by pulling his coat about there being a contract out on them-- a demonstration of natural cautiousness learned through years of experienced that seemed suddenly to have disappeared. Moreover, professionals who have to work the warring street never react with the sort of bland confusion our heroes displayed to the notion of having a contract out on one's self.  This kind of what seemed slip ups from a Hollywood writer who's not really into that life seemed part of the I-don't-know-why efforts to keep much of the movie light-hearted.  Cops on NIGHT patrol, in particular, talk more about what they see around them as they drive through the streets than constantly distract teach other by blinding kidding with one another.  And, as if to compound the error, after what seemed completion of the film after the funereal, we get a message-- something like, "earlier that day"-- and we see in morning light our boys-in-blue joking madly with each other in the car.  Uniformed cop's just don't work three consecutive tours (since the shootout occurred at night), and we get the wild laughter rubbed in our face again as a parting shot.  Why?  What was that supposed to mean?  Something came over the radio, but the guffaws made it impossible to hear what that was.  I still don't know what the audience was supposed to get out of that.  It left us with a final sour note, indicative of a strain of unrealistically stupid comic relief that was forced into and throughout the movie.  It's as if the people who made the movie insisted on getting their inner adolescent out by forcing a slightly "animal house" refrain throughout the movie.  That is a poor substitute for the kind of strained gallows humor that actually runs among professionals working the streets (what we saw instead in this movie was more the sort of "hippie-cayay" of Bruce Willis DIE HARD fame).  I also got the sense that the authors wanted us to see the two cops as somehow set up-- the green vision suggested observation by the "big" police authorities (who tried to warn our guys of the risky position they had gotten themselves into when they stumbled over human trafficking), and the way the black-and-whites had arrived so late (compared to all the other times it took so much less time to get there).  But nothing was explicitly  made of any of that.  That too was to me part of the movie's engagement in over-suggestiveness, in an excess of innuendo. JUST TELL THE DAMN STORY without "vaguely" suggesting all sorts of ill-fitting subplots!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

But, as I say, the movie was quite good, and I'm sure that it was because of how overall good it was that I felt so piqued by the silly and (at least to me) inexplicable parts of the movie.  Of course, when I read the one and two star comments, now they amounted to missing the barn wall by a mile.  I never realized people would come to a movie with such childish expectations.  The CONSTANT cursing was probably one of the most realistic things about the movie.  That's what men do in combat-- as well as women who must join them in that threateningly defeminizing context.  When the film showed the beat up woman cop who had become the victim of a man-on-man type crime (her ridding partner had been stabbed in the eye by the same man), that's when the sheer courage of these women-in-a-violent-man's-world came through most brilliantly.  That part of portraying modern sexually-integrated police was well done: constant cursing being the great equalizer for common sharing of extreme dangerousness (both sexes did it in that context).
Great movie, good content, sad ending, but highly recommend. Gyllenhal is great, saw him in Jarhead, so he's a cool military character.

I had my preconceptions before I watched the film, but very quickly they dissolved and what I found rather than the usual utterly violent, gritty, angry, tough American cop drama, was a film that although about two police officers working in Los Angeles' very dangerous South Central area, known for violent gangs and big drug dealers and murders and violent crimes by the dozen, is actually a bromance, about two friends on the same 'beat' telling jokes to each other, swearing, laughing, being offensive and making sleazy jokes about their women, you know typical guys everywhere, as they ride around their pitch in LA. What happens, and I won't go over the plot or spoil it for you, is they cross serious players and then the film kicks into another gear as they become marked men. Both lead actors in the movie are very good and watchable and convincing, Jake Gyllenhaal and Michael Pena, who play the cop buddies, and there is an outstanding performance by an actor called Maurice Compte who plays 'Big Evil'; not a guy you'd want to cross in an alley on a light night let alone a dark night!

All in all, a very enjoyable, if violent, cop movie with a difference.

End of Watch (2012)

Just got done watching "End of Watch" and i had to put up a few thoughts about it. I thought this was a pretty terrific movie. If The Wire captures what it means to be a police detective, End of Watch perfectly portrays the average completely crazy/totally boring day of patrolmen on a tough urban beat. The partnership between the two cops was fun to watch and very emotional at times. I'm not a rah-rah-rah police booster at all, but it's nice to see a film where cops aren't all portrayed as inept and/or corrupt a-holes, or as superhuman crime-stoppers, but regular people doing a hard job the best way they can. And be prepared to dry your eyes by the end.

I'm taking note of some of these other reviews here. There are a bunch of 1 star reviews for "too much bad language"... somebody actually said, "you need to do a better job with your ratings!" First off, this is not a one-star film by any means, no matter what the criteria (I took a star off because the director cheated a little too much with the first person POV shots). You give a movie one star because its not well made, because it's not a good film; you don't a give movie one star because it has some words you don't like. Second, it's a slice of life action drama about two young cops working South Central and East L.A., and it's RATED R. All I can say is, what the fu.. were you expecting?

*****

End of Watch (2012)

Starring: Jake Gyllenhaal, Michael Pea, America Ferrara, Anna Kendrick
Written & Directed By: David Ayers

This is an entertaining, if a little predictable, cop/buddy movie.

What lets it down though is the 'found footage' idea.  The cops spend a few minutes at the beginning showing the cameras that they will be wearing and capturing footage on, then the whole documentary-style gets forgotten about, with some shots that could definitely not have been filmed by them.

In fact, this movie would have been just as good if it had just been filmed in a traditional style.

I like found footage movies - where the style adds something to the story.  Good examples are The Dinosaur Project and Cloverfield.

This isn't one of them - but it's quite entertaining all the same.
Was a great movie!  Good story line and lots of action.  Wish it would've ended differently, but I would watch again.

One of my fondest memories of early childhood is plopping down in front of the TV at 8 p.m. for my favorite show, Adam 12, with a little pepperoni pizza my dad would pick up from the neighborhood shop.  It was a weekly ritual.  Boys wanted to be cops back then, or firemen, or soldiers.  Men they looked up to.  And Adam 12 was, at the time, considered pretty realistic, or at least cops said it was the most like the bouts of the mundane with spurts of danger that was actual police work.  Any buddy cop show gets measured against it for me.  The issue, of course, is that Adam 12 was a product of its time, meaning that as much as it showed people at their worst, it never quite ground under its own weight in depravity and hopelessness.  At its center was the assurance that the police were doing something meaningful.

End of Watch is Adam 12 on heroin, in an alley and being pissed on awake by the next knuckle-dragging lowlife that will brutalize it.  It's one of those movies that traffics in the worst of people and offers no answers nor hope.  The police might as well be zookeepers, or maybe landscapers who just keep coming to mow the lawn because they're paid, knowing full well it will grow back again next week for no other purpose than to keep them employed.  It's jazzed up with the standard macho, smart ass posturing that passes for depth, especially when we're young.  To make it topical and I guess cliched, the white and brown leads (a-series-of-triangles Jake Gyllenhaal and happy-scrappy-sappy Michael Pena) trade racially-tinged barbs with each other, you know, to be edgy but also show they really love each other as comrades in arms.  It uses the shaky cam both to keep the budget low and to give it verisimilitude, `cause we all go through life bobbing around or fliming ourselves.

Insight never really appears.  Instead, we get smart ass quips or repackaged homilies about the meaing of life.  Lots of statements that end in "bro" and "dude."  Witness, when one  partner asks the other about how to know if he should marry his girlfirend:

"My grandma  . . . was really deep, man.  She's seen it all. Know what I'm saying? . . . Can you live without her?

Really?  That's it?  Can you live without her?  That's the best she could come up with after 50 or 60 years on planet Earth?

Here's another gem.

"Janet's pregnant."

"WHUUTTTTTTTTTTT?"

The problem with End of Watch is that these moments of truth are as deep as anything gets.  It's one of those movies that cloaks its emptiness in poses, stares, and attitude.  No wonder nobody knows nothing.  But they're not afraid to proceed as though they do.

Fans of nihlism will tell me I just don't get it.  The lack of a point is the point, like life.  Survival is all there is.  That makes it real.  Yeah?  A bowel movement is real too, but that doesn't mean I want to watch it for 90 minutes.  I expect a little more out of art than I do out of a bowel movement.

Critics went nuts about this movie when it came up, so I suppose I had unrealistic expectations.  But, really, Southland does the same thing every week.  So did Colors.  So did Fort Apache, the Bronx.  Even then, I didn't feel stupider and like taking a shower after watching them.  I do give it props though for all the unapologetic product placement - Starbucks, Red Bull, Barbasol shaving cream - good job, boys.  Brand names get tossed around almost as often as the F word.  Almost.
Found footage of LA beat cops, doing their job, living life, having romance, and fighting the bad guys.  Highly recommended.

"End of Watch" runs with the idea that everything is getting recorded today.  It shows the viewpoint of the urban police officer on duty and how the job affects lifestyle, as well as a window into the life of a gang member. The cinematography and dialog are raw and realistic and often entrancing.  This is not a boring movie.

The problems with the movie are pretty overwhelming, however.  Although there is much foreshadowing, there is very little plot. The protagonists barely scratch the top of a sinister drug cartel operation, yet they are powerless to even investigate it.  Then they go about their duties and lives until they accidentally turn over a proverbial stone that gets them into big trouble without their even realizing it. The "boss" bad guys are practically an afterthought and play a very insubstantial part of the action.

The acting is great, but the characterization in pretty much stock. The policemen are all portrayed as flawless knights of justice, while the gang members are caricatures of evil incarnate (going so far as to name the leader "Head Evil").

Its an entertaining glorification of the LAPD but there is so little resolve of any of the issues it broaches that it feels incomplete. Think of the show "COPS" crossed with a indie character study film.

The good parts are really good but this movie is just ok overall.
This is one of the best cop movies I've seen.  It is really a great drama, and really captures the spirit of the day.
