Most of them should be given lots of respect, because they give it to us.  They help us. they don't try to hurt anyone unless they are being confronted badly by someone. This movie doesn't even deserve 1 star.  there are other movies that are much better.

'End of Watch', is the only cop film ever to capture the spirit of interaction between 2 ghetto cops and the sort of comments they make to each other while patrolling.  In my case, being a minority (3rd Generation Japanese-American), similar to Mike Pena's Hispanic character in this film, paired with a testosterone-fueled white male partner, who was quick with the ethnic slurs, reminded me of working with Bruce Kameg at the 1st Precinct in the late 1970s.  I read many of the reviews of the film here, on Amazon.com and it's interesting that people either loved and endorsed the film or HATED it, with little reaction in-between those 2 extremes.  There are many cop-haters in the world and some who saw this film said they much preferred 'Training Day'. The reason is obvious to me-the horribly 'bad' cop portrayed by Denzel Washington enabled those cop haters to reinforce their already negative opinions of how corrupt and rotten cops are.  Other negative reviews came from law enforcement types who are desk jockeys, paper shufflers or have worked only in suburban areas, where the big call of the night is "a drunk at the 7-Eleven'.  They are in no position to judge the authenticity of this film, because their experiences are so different, they might as well have taken place on another planet.  Ghetto policing is a whole different experience and it's a young man's game, often performed by coppers with a high school education, at best. Some critics didn't like the "immaturity" of the characters.  Like it or not, that depiction is real, not about ALL ghetto cops, but many.  A flippant attitude can be essential for mental survival in an insane environment.  Some said the camera was too jerky and watching the action made them sick.  Welcome to the real world of ghetto cops-in particular the fight near the beginning and the jolting car crash, which began the final action scene.  The jerky camera action really 'put you there', making me feel like I was back on the street.  It might not be 'pleasant' to experience, but it is realistic.  On my first night on patrol, (I was still in the academy) I was sent to the Vernor Pct for 'In Service training'.  I rode in the back of a patrol car, with an experienced 2 man crew. After sliding back and forth on the back seat,  racing from one priority call to another,  and drawing my gun 7 or 8 times in a single night, I felt like I'd been on a roller coaster for 8 hours.  I said to myself " I don't think I can do this s*** for 25 years."  But some of us did adapt to that crazy world and I remained on uniformed street patrol for 25 years, on Detroit PD.  Other negative reviewers (and there were MANY with this objection), stated they couldn't stand the obscene language that was so pervasive in 'End of Watch'.  Go back and watch the film again.  Although the cops are prone to swearing (which is accurate), 90% of the F-bombs in the film are spoken by ghetto gang members-welcome to reality.  Again, this was totally realistic and the 'emotional violence' which Joseph Wambaugh recognized as a major component of the police experience is captured perfectly by the black actor who fights the Hispanic cop at the beginning of the film.  I read that he is in fact a real gang member and street guy and the torrent of obscenity and disrespect that flowed from his mouth in that scene was 100% similar to the verbal abuse I listened to, for 25 years.  This also transported me back in time, to hear that obscene dialogue.
Most of the severe critics of this film are basing their opinions on what?  Their years of working at Dunkin Donuts or perhaps the many police movies they've watched?  The director of this film wanted to get it right and the 2 main actors spent months riding along with LAPD and LA Sherriff's crews, to get a feel for what they actually say and do, while working.  Learning of their preparation for these roles was what nudged me to go see the film.  It is very accurate on many levels-I know, because I've lived much of that experience.  The only thing that was way over the top, was the amount of shooting at the end.  Even in ghetto policing, that is not nearly as prevalent as shown in this movie and when it does happen, it's usually over a lot quicker than the prolonged gun battle at the end of this movie.  But that is typically Hollywood  and is inserted to add box office appeal.  The basic premise of the film required one or both of the officers to die at the end, but this could have been accomplished in a much briefer space of time.  I believe one reason response time was prolonged in the film, is that cops who call for assistance always 'perceive' that it takes forever for help to arrive, even if it is a matter of seconds or a few minutes.
Other aspects of the film which have been panned:

 By my calculations, I made over 15,000 traffic stops in my career and I never had the occupants of a stopped car come-out shooting, as was shown in the opening scene of this film.  However,  this DOES occasionally happen and footage captured recently on real life police dashboard cams, shows that the scenario looks VERY similar to what was depicted in 'End of Watch'.  In another traffic stop scene in the film, a citizen's gun arm is grabbed by a cop, just as he tries to shoot the cop.  MANY ghetto cops have grabbed a firearm out of the hands of a hostile citizen.  I once grabbed the barrel of a .12 gauge shotgun and deflected it away from me, after walking-up behind a armed citizen who had just shot at his neighbor (it later turned-out this citizen had two prior murder convictions on his rap sheet).

As to the scene where Pena takes off his gun to fight an abusive citizen, that also DOES happen occasionally.  I know of a FEMALE Detroit cop, who did that and whipped a strapping 22 year old young man, with a big mouth. They teach in the academy never to do this, but Pena's character was a ring boxer, which was revealed in one of the unfortunately deleted scenes. So he was capable of doing things the average cop would not attempt to do.

Other negative reviewers of the film resented the fact that cops were portrayed as occasional heroes in the film.  I never crawled along the floor of a building engulfed in a raging fire, to save occupants of an apartment building before the Fire Department arrived, but this happened to my partners one night, when I was off.  Going-in to a situation like that, with no adequate fire retardant clothing or breathing apparatus is nothing short of heroic and would be like expecting a fireman without a gun to take-on an armed felon. Yes, my partners did that, in a Cass Corridor apartment building and they saved some lives. One of them (Michael T. Walsh), happens to be the son of a Detroit fireman.
In short, many of the experts who have condemned this film don't have any idea what they're talking about.
My final comment on this, is to all the cop haters and also the chairborne desk jockey types, who never get out on the street and care only about getting promoted.  Your reasons for hating this film are obvious.  As to the bluenoses who can't stand hearing dirty words in a film, their objections should in no way reflect on whether this film is an accurate depiction of reality, in big city policing. On the contrary, the horrible language is just one more realistic aspect of this film. Patrolling the Cass Corridor of Detroit, in the 70s-80s was very similar.  'End of Watch' has nailed the ghetto policing experience more accurately than any Hollywood film, to date.

*** This review may contain spoilers ***

'End of Watch' was written in six days by Writer/Director David Ayer. The story focuses on two LAPD cops, Brian Taylor (Jake Gyallanhaal) and Mike Zavala (Michael Pea), on patrol in their squad car in South Central Los Angeles. Taylor is shooting a film project (not sure why) and both officers wear miniature cameras on their lapels. The idea is to give the narrative a documentary feel. At other times, however, Taylor and Zavala are shot from a third party perspective--one wonders if this is supposed to be shot in a real-life documentary style (in real- time), who is supposed to be filming Taylor and Zavala, independent of Taylor's 'flim project'? Obviously filming the entire story from the two officers' perspectives, just wasn't working and Mr. Ayer was forced to adopt the more traditional third party viewpoint, for a good number of scenes.

I assume that what Ayer did here was to take some of the more sensational 'inner city' real-life cop stories and condense them into a more fast-paced narrative. Hence, some of Taylor and Zavala's encounters are quite gripping. I'm thinking particularly of the scenes where they find the two children duct-taped in the closet while the parents waste away in a crack den, another scene where a whole group of human trafficking victims are found as well as the discovery of dismembered corpses, victims of a particularly vicious drug cartel.

Not all of the police officers' machinations ring true. When Zavala decides to fight Tre, a Bloods gang member, and afterward refuses to charge him with assault, it's difficult to believe that a police officer, would put himself in harm's way, merely to earn a gang member's respect (the beat down could have resulted in serious injuries for Tre, along with a lawsuit--resulting in Zavala's job being placed in jeopardy).

More unlikely is the idea that the drug cartel would go out of their way to target LAPD members on a number of occasions. Recall this happens twice in the film: the first time, one cop is stabbed in the eye and another one is severely beaten in the face. Then there is the film's climax, where the protagonists face the 'end of watch'. I realize that in Mexico, cops are targeted all the time by drug gangs and cartels but I have not heard that many stories about American law enforcement being directly challenged by these out of country lawbreakers. Would it really be in these cartel's best interest to directly target LAPD officers? After all, they're in a business where they don't want to call too much attention to themselves. And by assaulting and even murdering LAPD officers, that would lead to the enmity of an entire department. I realize that the cartel hire the local gang bangers to do their dirty work but such select targeting of LAPD by the cartels would result in vastly increased scrutiny as well as retaliation by law enforcement.

'End of Watch' also covers the private lives of Taylor and Zavala. Most of the time, they rib one another but also display passionate displays of loyalty (particularly during the tragic climax). The ribbing gets a little tiresome as there's a little too much of it during the film. I particularly was annoyed by the little flashback that was tacked on after the funeral. Why was it necessary to serve up another scene with the partners once again busting on one another. The crudity of their jokes obviously is designed to show that they are 'ordinary' people but showing that directly following the solemnity of the funeral, diminishes their heroic stature.

The 'End of Watch' climax is heart-pounding as the officers are cornered by gang member mercenaries, conscripted by the drug cartel seeking revenge. But the gang members themselves are so over the top, that we can't take them seriously. And the awkward way in which they are taken out, hardly seems realistic at all.

'End of Watch' features two excellent performances by Gyallanhaal and Pea. There are also a series of fairly shocking scenes involving what LAPD officers have encountered during their travails while on the 'beat'. I didn't buy everything, particularly the idea that drug cartels would invite trouble by specifically targeting LAPD officers. Still, there's enough here to keep your interest, despite the obvious exaggerations.

The first thing I heard about End of Watch was its realistic and moving portrayal of male friendship. I watched the film with that expectation and it did not disappoint. End of Watch follows the patrols of Brian Taylor (Jake Gyllenhaal) and Mike Zavala (Michael Pea), two policemen in South Central Los Angeles. We watch them drive the streets, engage in shootouts, encounter violence against a female policewoman, catch drug smugglers, discover a torture house, and stumble on a human trafficking hideout. But these are all supporting elements to the relationship between Taylor and Zavala.

Conversations during the late night patrol shift, figuring out who to marry, sharing memories--these are the building blocks of the film. There is no single "bad guy" who they're trying to take down. While there is a group of criminals that come to the fore and end up being given a directive to neutralize Taylor and Zavala, the focus remains on the friendship.

That's the highlight of End of Watch. It's worth watching just for the relationship between these two characters. They are partners facing a city rife with Hispanic-Black ethnic tensions, drugs, guns, and trafficking. There is definitely some social commentary when it comes to ethnic divisions in urban environments and the disturbing persistence of crime in American cities. End of Watch also pays tribute to the great service policemen provide to society, despite the cynical attitude we've grown accustomed to when it comes to law enforcement, and the sacrifices their families and loved ones must make.

Well color me impressed. Out of all the movies I've seen recently this was the one I was expecting to let me down. On the contrary, it was exactly what I was looking for and then some. End of Watch was a thrill ride from start to finish and I honestly couldn't have asked for anything more.

End of Watch follows the story of two policemen, Brian Taylor (Jake Gyllenhaal) & Mike Zava (Michael Pena), as they do police work (shocking). The film opens with Brian and Mike in the middle of a chase while Gyllenhaal gives us some spiel about policemen and how they're important to keeping order, yada yada yada. The beginning of the film also shows off what I think is this film's biggest fault: the way it was filmed.

As you watch End of Watch you'll see the camera switch from regular, steady recording to that of a home movie. This is because Brian is taking a film class and he's recording police activities for a project he's working on. Now this wouldn't be a big problem if it would have stayed within the police work, but it doesn't. Almost every scene has at least one person with a damn camera so this recording style follows you throughout the entire hour and 40 minutes. The Mexican gang had a video camera (because that makes sense), Brian carried the camera to a quinceanera, during his wedding someone had a camera, I mean it just never stops.

With that said, I'm pretty impressed that this is the film's only fault. One of its biggest achievements, on the other hand, has to be just how well the story is written. I mean it is intense. It does a great job of sucking you in and keeping your attention throughout the entire thing. What's even better is that it's filled with characters that you both like and care for. You don't want to see Brian or Mike get hurt, you want them to succeed in whatever crazy task they accept while on the job, and you want to see their relationships work out. Sadly, we don't always get what we want as this film proves that not every story has a happy ending.

This connection wouldn't have been possible if it wasn't for the fantastic performances from Gyllenhaal and Pena. I've only seen these men in a handful of films, but they've given solid performances in everything I've seen from them. With that said, I think Gyllenhaal really stepped up in this and Pena might have given the performance of his career. It's some really powerful stuff and the ending is bound to leave you speechless.

On top of the two main guys you have Natalie Martinez and Anna Kendrick playing Gabby (Mike's wife) and Janet (Brian's girlfriend), respectfully. Then you have David Harbour, Frank Grillo, and America Ferrera each playing someone working on the force. In the Mexican gang you have Big Evil played by Maurice Compte and La La played by Yahira Garcia. While I don't think any of these actors had enough screen time to go toe-to-toe with Gyllenhaal and Pena, everyone gave solid performances even if I didn't necessarily like their characters.

Overall Score: 9/10 - End of Watch proves to be one of those films that delivers in what it sets out to do. It's not often that I leave a film blown away by what I saw, but End of Watch is one of those films. The story is gripping and the movie is driven forward by some fantastic leads. I'll give you a warning though, this is not for the squeamish. There's a few decapitated heads along with a male officer who has a knife stuck in his eye and a female officer with her face beaten in. If you think you can handle something like that then I can't recommend this movie enough. Definitely one of the best cop movies I've seen.

I went in expecting this to be an entirely different movie; this was a good thing.  The writers did a great job with the dialogue, and the actors pulled it off so convincingly (especially the leads) that it was easy to forget you were watching something scripted.
Given how much the movie sucked us in, some of the scenes were difficult to watch; which was likely an intentional and appropriate choice by the creators, as the brutality and horror of these scenes turned out to be meaningful, rather than just for shock value.
I plan to recommend to all my friends, and watch it at LEAST once more, if not buy it and put on a treasured section of my shelf.

I spent an hour and a half with these guys and I don't have any better picture of them than I do of any other high-fiving coors-guzzling broham. You can make a buddy movie. You can make a cop-drama. But if you make a character driven piece you better make damn sure your characters are worth the time.

Also featured in this film are stereotypes (of practically everyone) and a really bad, lazy ending. I did enjoy some of the cinematography though.

End of Watch is one of those films that you have seen many times before in many TV shows but it has so many great moments that you begin to care for the leads and the film. Jake Gyllenhaal and Michael Pena are young police officers who bust a drug cache and make enemies south of the border. David Ayer has been writing about crooked cops for a while, he wrote Training Day and Harsh times about corrupt cops on the verge of insanity. However in this film, the cops are actually heroes - they are green, clean and brave. Brian Taylor (Gylenhall) and Mike ( Mike Zavala) are best friends and honest police officers. They love each other , their families and are brothers in every sense of the way. On their daily watch, they investigate different cases some involving fires, burglaries and warfare between black and hispanic gangs. Most of the footage in the film is found footage apparently on a camera that Taylor loves to carry with him through the film. This is great film and a reminder to the rest of us who don't like their jobs because there are other jobs out there which are far more dangerous. 5 stars. 4/7/2013

I'll be honest; I almost didn't bother watching this.  Buddy cop films are so overdone these days, I'm sick of watching them.  Add to that the fact that Jake Gyllenhaal is NOT a name that evokes any confidence in me as of late and you had this film that I didn't care if I saw or not.  Despite the acclaim it got and the great ink for the central performances and the critics and audiences reacting so favorably, I seriously had no interest in seeing this; at all.  So, to say that the biggest shock for me this year was my actual adoration of the film (and of Gyllenhaal's magnificent performance) would not be an understatement.  This movie was really, really good.

Sharply written, edgy, steeped in a really slick sense of comradery and anchored by two beautifully fleshed out performances; `End of Watch' will keep you glued to every frame.

The film is shot almost like a documentary, utilizing gritty camera angles to bolster audience reaction.  It follows the relationship between two cops, Brian and Mike.  They are reckless and childish and yet devoted to their jobs and the responsibility they have towards the people depending on them.  They joke around, indulge in inappropriate talk and bicker like kids, yet at the end of the day they are brothers at heart and are truly stand up guys.  As the film progresses we see them push themselves in order to get more out of their jobs.  They follow up on leads, do their own investigating and uncover some serious stuff.  In the meantime, they agitate some local deviants who don't take their intrusiveness lightly.

Gyllenhaal and Pena make a great team here.  They capture every layer of these men and have an infectious chemistry with one another.  The rest of the cast is certainly up to par, but these two men form a great foundation for the film itself.

It's a great change of pace for the average cop film.  It speaks to the honor of the men in uniform and makes them real people, are may have flaws but are certainly not flawed.
Great movie. Can't recommend for youngsters or sensitive audiences. In many respects, an extremely accurate portrayal. Let's be careful out there.

Gritty, Hyper realistic ridealong with two of LA's finest in a cop movie that takes place in the streets. Hand held camera work making it all seem as if you're in the black& white with these two partners - played well by Michael Pena and Jake Gyllenhaal. In doing their jobs, and doing it well, they get on the wrong side of a vicious drug gang in the mean streets of Los Angeles and  put the term "watch your backs" into overdrive. Scary good. White knuckle suspense and violence that seems truthful even as it comes at you from out of nowhere. Beautifully rendered characters in both the writing and the acting. The direction puts boots on the ground and lets you move when they do, duck when they do, and feel the trapped, clammy sweats of police officers going in harm's way.

Seldom, in the genre of Cops n' Robbers does a film so realistically offer up a glimpse of street life from all perspectives......dizzying scenes shot via hand-held camera place the viewer in harms way in the everyday struggle to "protect and serve" with the men and women of the LAPD.  Yes, there are many of the usual police cliches mixed with the rich ethnic jargon heard in the melting pot of American Culture, never more evident than in The City of the Angels!  The film touches upon their personal lives and loves, weaknesses and strengths as most other Police dramas do however this film bonds the two as few others have---like the catalyst solidifying their fatal belief that each is invincible in "watching my partner's back" amidst the danger and horrors of law enforcement........Be prepared to meet a new kind of evil, that which kills without feeling, preys upon the weak and defenseless, and bleeds the humanity from its inhabitants with arrogance and indifference----Jake Gyllenhaal and Michael Pena masterfully play off one another as the infallible street cops whose bravado is matched by only by an over abundance of testosterone until one fatal bust goes down...whatch gonna do when they come for you?

It is a little different how this movie plays out. Most of it is filmed from the perspective of a home video. Of course there are too many gun battles and pursuits when most of police work is pretty uneventful marked with periods of sheer terror and excitement. This movie displays some serious high and low points of being a police officer. It took on a challenge to show what some have to deal with within the limits of a couple hour movie. They actually did a fairly decent job.

I've been in Law Enforcement since 1996 and I have had some of these same experiences in my life. Not all at once and I certainly never had to deal with the Cartel or anything like that, but I've been in pursuits. I've been scared to death because of the unknown and I've witnessed some of the horrible things people do to one another. This movie depicts a great deal of this.

I personally truly enjoyed watching the film "End of Watch."  I do not think however, that it would be everyone's taste.  Perhaps that is why it did not make a great deal of money in the theaters.  First, I will tell you what I liked about the film.  I enjoyed the interaction between the two main characters played by Michael Pena and Jake Gyllenhaal.  Also, the film showed their interaction with their families, Pena has a wife that he obviously loves greatly and Gyllenhaal meets the girl of his dreams and ends up marrying her in the movie.  The intensity of their relationships adds texture to the movie.  Also, Pena's character and his wife have their first child.

I did not particularly care for the fact that Gyllenhaal's character was filming everything for a film class that he was taking.  It kind of made things a bit confusing and created a lot of undue tension between the other officers and his character.

The film had a truly great amount of violence.  The most violent scene showed another officer getting stabbed in the eye.  Perhaps the violence did further the plot but it was really graphic.  There was also a scene of a woman being raped that was graphic as well.

There are many stereotypes in the movie, but that just may be the way things are in Los Angeles.  The police in the movie are mostly white and they are trying to keep the neighborhoods around them from blowing up everyday.  Drugs are prevalent and guns are readily available to everyone.  As a matter of fact, it seems in this film, that the people on the streets, have more weapons than the police and of course, they also outnumber the officers.  This makes for continuing tension and some give and take between the street people and the authorities.

The police are quick to honor the work that they do with awards and commendations. The characters are portrayed as heroes but one of them has to give up his life for the cause.

All in all, I enjoyed the movie but I would caution others that if they feel squeamish about blood and gore, they should skip this movie.

The two main characters were realistic
(they were portrayed as family-men, brothers in arms and flawed individuals as well). I can't speak to the realism of the plot and scenarios, but it was stripped down and enlightening.

Not much to say. Its a great police movie. Its more about the life of 2 officers than an action movie like the trailer portrays though. Plenty of action don't get me wrong.

*SEMI ENDING SPOILER-but I feel anyone with family in law enforcment needs to be warned*

If you have family in law enforcment like I do be prepared for the end. I don't care how old you are, how much of a man you are, or how big your brass balls are. The ending will be emotional.

I honor the men and women who can work in law enforcement, and highly recommend this film as a kick in the balls action film.

Somewhat difficult to watch this after all the Chris Dorner drama with the real-life LAPD.  In fact, those residents who have a more proximal and years-long relationship with the LAPD might also have to view this film with an entirely new mindset that will require them to actually sympathize with the LAPD instead of throw their shoes at the screen. But it is possible.  The two cop protagonists are young guys who don't carry the same baggage of racial disdain that their older peers do.  They are the LAPD we ought to have--able to identify, mix with all sorts of people and see them as humans first.  These guys would never fire 50 shots at a blue van with two elderly hispanic women inside figuring the occupant is a large black man.  They arrest people, they don't execute them hoping to avoid paperwork as a result.

End of Watch is an entertaining and even sad cop story about duty on a tough beat.  Given the horrifying stuff these cops run into on a daily basis, (crimes done exclusively by usual cast of scary black and latino people) you gotta ask, "who in their right mind would even want that job?"

One of the worst police movies, if not the worst, I have seen.  Totally unrealistic.  No officer is going to carry a camera around and video himself while on duty.  No officer, unless he is on drugs, is going to get in a fight with a complainant while his partner watches.  Hopefully, no officer with the demeanor of these two knuckleheads is going to keep their job for more than a few months.  They obviously missed the psychological screening part of the hiring process.  It is totally make-believe and I hate to see my life's work portrayed in this manner.

If you want a good idea of what it is really like, take a look at Southland.  Not perfect but much more realistic.

As a former police officer (now a lawyer) and my husband a former police officer (he is a fireman now) - we thoroughly enjoyed this movie.

The conversations were very realistic, the joking behavior and mannerisms.  This movie made you cry and laugh.  It was violent at times, and showed the other side of the law.  It also accurately portrayed that officers are people too, and that they have lives outside of the Department and Badge.

This movie allowed others to see that - while you may be upset at getting pulled over for speeding or in an accident with no injuries - that you have NO IDEA where the cop who you are dealing with was.  He/she could have been investigating a dead body, a burglary, a rape, a child abuse.  They could have just come from court where someone was released on a technicality, and they are going to break the law, again.

I also really enjoyed the fact that it allowed normal public people to see that some cops love their job, and want to help society.  And that there are some complacent cops.  The complacent cops tend to be the ones rewarded, and the ones who dig for "the dirt" and help to get the bad guys off the street - can be the officers placed in danger and targeted.

We bought this movie and watch it frequently - it reminds us of the time we both spent on the street.  While our experiences were similar - we wouldn't trade them for anything!

I hope everyone else is just as appreciative as we are about the men and women who choose to devote their lives to this profession.  It is hard and thankless job. I am thankful there is a movie like this to capture and expose people to the lives of police officers.

David Ayer wrote "Training Day", an exciting, gritty and complex police drama which landed Denzel Washington
his second Oscar, his first as the best actor.
This film is Ayer's debut as a director of his own script.
It is basically a story about two LA cops who are partners and good friends, Jake Gyllenhaal and Michael Pena.
Gyllenhaal's character loves to use his digital camera during his daily patrol which the director used the shaky
camera technique to land some realism but annoying and caused dizziness to the viewers.
There is not much of a story other than about the two cops daily routine and family life.
For the two lead actors, Michael Pena gave a more nuanced and controlled performance.
The unexpected tragedy at the end seems forced and does not induce much sympathy from the viewers.

Being a police officer in south central Los Angeles is a scary thing. At least it is in David Ayer's End of Watch, a movie so well made and shot in a semi-documentary style, that some have viewers have mistaken for "found footage" , that you never question it even when the violence reaches extreme proportions.
 It feels real there for in the mind's eye it is. An unflinching and edgy portal of  big city police life. At times it's a heroic look at police work, at others it is a violent thriller and a dark and depressing look at the daily evil hidden behind locked doors, at times it even feels like a horror story.
 With a bald and buffed bad ass Jake Gyllenhaal and the excellent character actor Michael Pena giving the performances of their respected careers, at least up to this point. Starring as two dedicated LAPD patrol men. They are best friends, brothers they say, they believe in the service that they offer to those in need.  They don't aim to be heroes, even after a heroic deed, they still say they do not feel like heroes. They are just average realistically portrayed guys.
 They find themselves in over there heads in the three major food groups: "drugs, money and guns". Just reinstated after a justified on-duty shooting, these "ghetto gunfighters" prove to be a more than a little reckless when they begin an unauthorized investigation that leads to Mexican drug cartels operating in L.A.
  End of Watch recalls the late Dennis Hopper's great, but largely forgotten Colors, which starred Robert Duvall and Sean Penn. Colors was to cop movies in the `80's what Platoon was to war films.
 So much of End of Watch depends on it's two leads, and fortunately they deliver. Gyllenhaal and Pena are two of our best actors working today, here you will see a different side of Gyllenhaal and a star making turn by Pena. They camaraderie and friendly banter make these characters seem more flesh and blood than in most movies.
 Written and directed by David Ayers, who's well known for his screenplays for movies like Training Day and, uh, the original Fast and the Furious movie. He has also directed two prior films, the reasonable Christian Bale-Freddy Rodriguez thriller Harsh Times and the dismal and dire Keanu Reeves and Chris Evan starrer Street Kings. Up to know Ayers has appeared to be somewhat overrated, even Training Day peters out in a terrible and obvious third act. But here with End of Watch Ayers really finds his niche and proves for once to be a first rate filmmaker, perhaps one coming into his own.
 This is also a change of direction for Ayers. Not an obvious one, at least not on first inspection, but it most certainly is. Instead of corruption in the department, he has good guys here, the new direction is a good one for him. Ayers seems fascinated by cops, LAPD ones precisely, but has never had the nerve to celebrate them before, he feels comfortable in doing so.
 I think a lot of people will be surprise by just how funny the sharply observed dialogue is, as two punctuate the grim realities in the film. A down and dirty gritty film for sure, but the amiable lead performances make it one of the most enjoyable.
 End of Watch doesn't offer much new and like a lot off movies these days it relies to much on shaky cam movements, but it does take us into the heart of darkness that is rarely explored in movies any more, the harsh realities of this world. Like all the best movies, it is more entertaining than you might suspect, and make no mistake this is one of the year's very best.

  The final third of the movie really didn't make much sense.  Why did the street gang go after these two regular patrol officers?  What did they hope to gain?  Didn't they understand the risk they would be taking?  And after the two officers left the apartment where they took shelter, why did they continue to hunt down their attackers (even though they were clearly outgunned), instead of trying to hide and protect themselves until help arrived?

  Overall, a single typical episode of the TV series Southland is much better than this movie, giving more meaningful stories about the lives of LA police officers (with stronger characterization).

Every so often and yet not often enough, a movie comes along that rocks me to the core. 'End of Watch' is one of those movies. I thought this movie was fantastically made, brilliantly directed and superbly acted. I was on the edge of my seat throughout, I cared about the characters, I wanted to know what the outcome would be, I laughed, I gasped, I cried and was left with nothing but sheer admiration for everyone involved with this production.

The Movie was written and directed by David Ayers who you may or may not know as the director of 'Harsh Times' starring Christian Bale and the screenwriter for 'Training Day' with Denzel Washington and Ethan Hawke amongst other works.

The two principal characters in the movie are played by Jake Gyllenhaal and Michael Pena.

The movie centres on Brian Taylor (Jake Gyllenhaal) and Mike Zavala (Michael Pena), who are close friends and partners in the Los Angeles Police Department. Taylor is filming their police activities for a film project he's working on. After shooting two suspects following a high speed chase they are placed on suspension and return to work after they are cleared of any wrong doings. After staking out a house of a known drug user they follow and then pull over the man in a 4x4, who was seen taking a metal pot from a woman. As Zavala approaches the driver's window to make contact, the driver suddenly draws a gun and fires. After arresting the driver, Taylor removes the pot from the 4x4, and kicks it over, thus removing the lid. He finds an ornately-decorated .45 Colt automatic pistol, and a gold-plated AK-47 rifle, along with a large amount of money. They find out that the money and firearms are connected to a Mexican drug cartel operating in the notorious South Central area. A convict who they are familiar with and had a run in with earlier tells them that they have been marked for death. They don't really take this threat too seriously as all villains want to kill the LAPD in South Central.

Taylor has just got married and Zavala's wife has just given birth and now something will go down that will change both of their futures forever in a fast paced, emotionally charged drama that will have any discerning member of the public gripping the edge of their seat.

I  can't say enough about this movie. I thoroughly enjoyed it and everyone involved with it should be proud of what they have created. It is gritty, hard-edged, poignant, relevant, uncomfortable, frightening, shocking, disturbing, enlightening, pulsating and above all engrossing.

Seeing as one of my best friends is a fire-fighter and his wife a police officer, this movie makes me appreciate how unpredictable and difficult their jobs are, not that I didn't know that already. I know that comparing South Central to the Midlands in the UK is stretching it a little but in these harsh times (apologies to David Ayers) in doesn't matter what area in the world you are policing, it is a dangerous job. I think we should all doff our caps to police officers and fire-fighters around the world as they all risk their lives to keep us safe every day, sadly at times with very little credit.

The thing that strikes me about the movie is that it gels without ever seeming to be structured. What I mean by that is that it obviously is structured through the writing process but you can see that Ayers has used hours and hours of footage and edited the final piece to the footage used. This gives the movie that documentary type feel, especially with that added element of Taylor filming himself and his partner. This does not take away the fact that the craftsmanship is there for all to see. It is an astonishingly well put together movie and it exudes boldness without trying to be too clever.

The title itself 'End of Watch' comes from the real life tag that police officers use for cops who are killed on the job. There is a famous book entitled 'End of Watch: Chicago Police Killed in Line of Duty 1853-2006' that encapsulates this whole grisly circumstance. The book was written by Edward M Burke and Thomas J. O'Gorman and I am not sure how much of an influence it had on Ayers script or whether he did indeed take his idea from it. The book contains stories of 526 law officers from Chicago who died in the line of duty, including photographs and the circumstances in which they were killed. So that leads you to the question 'So they die in the movie?' Well, do they both die? Do they both live? You'll have to watch the movie to find out.

I like the way the opening shot is filmed from the drivers prospective of a police car as it chases a criminal in another vehicle. Jake Gyllenhaal narrates over this scene and it starts the film off with a bang. It also opens the way for the cam shots that are to come. I thought at first that I may be put off by the first-person cam view but to be honest it isn't used too much in the movie and when it is it is used well and is not off-putting in the least.

Ayer took hours of film footage to the editing room and it was a huge job to piece it all together. I think he did a fantastic job. Overall it took him thirteen months from writing the script, through transition to completion. That is not bad considering the subject matter and the things that an LAPD cop in South central goes through in any single day.

The movie is shot in colour but contains black and white scenes too due to the cam footage. The cinematographer on the movie was Roman Vasyanov and this was his most high profile film to date. He does a good job as everything seems to blend together and some of the shots as they travel along in the patrol car with the sun setting and the street lights dazzling are really effective.

The original score was provided and performed by David Sardy who has produced the scores for '21', 'The Green Hornet', 'Lock Stock and Two Smoking Barrels' and 'Wanted'. It fits in with the grittiness of the film and plays well off some of the music tracks from the soundtrack.

The movie was made on a budget of seven million dollars, which is not an awful lot by today's standards. I am pleased to say that it doubled that on its opening weekend and has grossed almost forty million to date and that is not including ant sales of the forthcoming DVD and Blue Ray. So in terms of commerciality, the movie can be deemed a success. David Ayers is known for his movies about the police and this is the flavour of his movies 'Harsh Times', 'Training Day' (script writer) and 'Street Kings'. I liked Harsh Times, thought Training day was brilliant but sadly didn't like Street Kings. End of Watch is by far his best movie for me and after Street Kings has put him back on the map.

Ayers Produced the movie too and Jake Gyllenhaal liked the project so much that he executive Produced and effectively put his money where his mouth was along with Ayers.

I would recommend this movie to anyone and I will freely admit that some people will not be able to look past the violence, gang related scenes and swearing but all I can say to that is each to their own and it is a shame because you are missing a cinematic treat and a master class in acting and a realistic portrayal of some of the bravest men and woman alive today. I apologise to all the cult fans of the original 'Precinct 13' movie but I think End of Watch is the best cop movie ever made. End of watch for me is a triumph and I give it five out of five stars.

Blue Ray gives the usual option of watching in high definition and high resolution sound as well as the digital version and the ULtraViolet option which allows viewers to watch their movies and TV shows in the Ultraviolet cloud. This lets consumers instantly stream and download to tablets, smartphones, computers and TVs. It will soon be available worldwide and and the time of this release was only available in the US and Canada.

The DVD extras include: The making of documentaries 'Fate with a Badge', 'In the Streets', 'Women on Watch', 'Watch Your Six' and 'Honors'.

Deleted Scenes and a feature Commentary with Writer and Director David Ayer are also included.

You can pick the this item up for between ten and sixteen pounds. The current Amazion price is sixteen pounds and nine pence.

 Lee Billingham

This is quite a realistic portrayal of what it is like for some LA cops to patrol in drug and gang infested areas of LA. It does not paint a pretty picture of LA. It could just as easily describe "burned out" areas of any major city in the U.S. It also likely sets some records for profanity in a movie. I watched it for its reality. But there are at least a few scenes that may offend blacks. It would probably have been just as accurate to show Hispanic and white racist gangs. The cop bravado is probably very isolated for LA cops, though I am sure it exists. There is definitely a macho police element. Part of this is just a Hollywood filter on it. But it does get at the inside the culture of many city police squads that have a "we're going to get them before they get us mentality."

Knew it would be intense as hell, but yesterday saw 'End of Watch' only to see maybe the best film about cops I've ever seen. Have never had a better idea of the day to day grind of being a police officer, a job where you risk your life every day for total strangers, and at the end of the day still can't leave it behind you. I've felt for a long time that Michael Pena is one of the best actors walking around working today, and this film was total confirmation of that - Jake Gyllenhaal, as well, turning in a performance equally real (the film comes off more like a documentary, it's that real, down to the chemistry of Pena and Gyllenhaal as partners sharing the same squad car). Visceral, full of tension, and so realistic in its depiction of a cop's life as to be unsettling, this is a must-see.

I sat down to watch another cop thriller, hoping it would be a pretty decent one. END of WATCH stood out in an unexpected way. It's a brutally realistic, super-violent, and gory film that, miraculously, shows just enough to avoid being cheaply gratuitous in any of these respects. While it's not Gyllenhaal's finest role, he's still quite good here as Officer Brian Taylor, and the acting in general is likewise. Many of the gangster-actors (some of whom apparently came from the background shown in this film) give especially strong performances.

Taylor and his partner (similarly well-played by Michael Pea) encounter violent rival gangs, drug cartels, house fires, mass murder, and human trafficking rings in an unusually rough section of South Central LA. The not-so-subtle hints that the top echelons of the LAPD (along with certain federal agencies) are bedfellows in some of the gangs' most appalling activities add an interesting twist. While the storyline is not perfect--e.g., some of the gangsters are amazingly bad shots --END of WATCH is better than any other film I've seen that portrays urban cops as soldiers in enemy territory. The two lead characters' family lives are also realistically shown, along with the sometimes friendly, sometimes not-so-friendly camaraderie and politics within the police division. Great dialogue!

This is another fictional "home-film documentary" related partly in first person by the protagonists, and another reason why I have to downgrade a little is that the sometimes jerky camcorder does nothing but annoy. I realize that many people like this technique; however, I don't see what it adds or why the story could not have not have been told from a standard third person POV.

Done in a documentary style, this drama goes beyond the surface cop dramas we've seen in the past and goes to a level of depth that makes us not only feel for the characters but live the moments they experience.  The characters come off not as realistic, but instead very real.  Much like Hurt Locker did for bringing Middle East warfare into our American psyche, this film puts us in the middle of the war fought each day by the police in our communities surrounded and outgunned by gangs and organized crime.  This movie goes beyond entertainment and makes you respect those who put their lives on the line with honor, duty and brotherhood to keep us all safe from evil.

Sick & Stupid Score: 7/3*

This is another movie about Los Angeles as a giant septic tank.

If you like straight-up cop movies, you will probably like this movie.  If you are tired of the I love you like a brother cops riding around in a patrol car, avoid this movie.  Also, if the somewhat goofy, out-of-control cop partners seem like a worn-out theme to you, avoid this movie.

I found no fault in the acting and was rather surprised at the creative scriptwriting, since I had no idea a sentence could be constructing by simply stringing together F-words.  However, I disliked this movie for both technical and philosophical reasons.

Technically, the movie is a camerawork disaster.  The movie unsuccessfully tries to merge cinma vrit techniques with standard cinematography.  There are cameras everywhere, and the audience has no idea whose view of events it is seeing.  Is this the cops personal camcorder, his vest camera, or the patrol car camera?  Or have we reverted to the set camera, and we are now getting the cinematographers point of view?

Philosophically, this movie raises a very serious social question, which it does not answer:  What is the purpose of LAPD?  When they are not trying to enjoy normal lives with friends and family, all we see in the film is our two beat cops rushing from one horrific, murderous scene to another.  Racial minorities rampage throughout the movie, taking and selling drugs, killing each other, killing cops, wrecking everything.  Our two hero cops seem to be making little or no progress.  The situation is hopeless.  The next question then arises, Why is the LAPD even wasting its time with these people?

________________________________
* The Sick & Stupid Score ranks movies from zero to ten in each category. For example, a Sick & Stupid Score of 5/5 indicates the movie is about average Sick and about average Stupid. A Score of 10/10 indicates the movie is so gross and idiotic no one should watch it; whereas a Score of 0/0 is a perfect movie.

End of Watch(released Sept/12)stars Jake Gyllenhaal as Brian Taylor,Michael Pea as Mike Zavala,Natalie Martinez as Gabby and Anna Kendrick as Janet,among others. This film is one that tries its darnedest to portray a "realism" between a couple of cops patrolling the mean streets of south L.A.The directors use portable hand held cameras in a myriad of angles to give the viewer a you-are-there feeling. Also Officer Taylor is constantly carrying around a hand held camera for a "project" he is doing. Convenient. However,as inventive as the producers of this film thought that would be,it is something that we have all see dozens of times. And THAT in itself wouldn't be so bad,if the slow and meandering stop-start of a plot didn't rain down a-plenty on this cop fest parade.
The story begins with a car chase,at the end of which our two protagonists,officers Taylor and Zavala,take down the occupants of a vehicle in short order. From here we become observers/flies on the wall,if you will,both visually and audially,into the officers banterings,thought processes and their friendship and careers,which bond them together. We also get a look into the regimentation and daily routine of a cop,as the two go from start of shift to end,answering various calls,some mundane,some not so.
Things start getting a little tight as the two inadvertently discover a human trafficking ring in a house. The Immigration and Customs Enforcement agency swoops in and takes control of the situation before they have a chance to say or do anything. On ICE agent tells them that this house is operated by a huge drug cartel and that they may have bitten off a little more than they can handle,and warns them to lay low. Time passes,Taylor gets married and the two,back out on the street,make another bust in a house. This time they discover a grisly scene with plenty of packed up drugs and body parts. This time the drug cartel sits up and takes notice and puts a hit out on the two.
A local bandito by the name of Big Evil and his posse of hacks,are given the job. The trick is to get the cops alone. They do this by having one of their members make them chase him in a vehicle. They follow him into an open aired apartment complex and the posse open fires on them with automatic weaponry. The two are temporarily pinned down in an apartment and barely manage to escape. They make their way along an alleyway,praying for backup. At one point they are fired on and Taylor gets it in the neck,bleeds profusely and passes out. As his partner hovers over him we hear a click. The camera rises to reveal Mr. Evil and his posse right behind Zavala. They open fire and he collapses to the ground. Backup arrives soon after and the resultant exchange of gunfire takes the entire posse down.
The film ends as Taylor attends his partners funeral and we see a flashback of the two in better times,riding in the patrol car.
The opening scene is where the film goes downhill. For all the realism it tries to portray,the take down of the occupants of the vehicle is just TOO Hollywood-ish. The occupants of the chased vehicle get out and start shooting. The officers get out and coolly and methodically take them down as if they were walking into a doughnut shop. Then they high five each other afterwards. Between calls received,the plot is a meandering one as they introduce each main character and sub characters. After a while,actually quite quickly,this on again,off again roller coaster wears very thinly. Very early on you start clock watching and can't wait for this thing to end. Never a good thing with a film. No matter how good the acting cast was,they just cannot overcome the sedentary plot. I might also ask,why is the excessive use of foul language,heard to such a degree here,frequently used as a writers tool to reenforce that"realism",when it needn't be?
Technically speaking the film is in its w/s a/r of 1:85:1 and s clear and crisp. There are no extras.
All in all a disappointment. The film tries to portray the lives of two L.A.cops in a gritty and "realistic" fashion,but the meandering stop and go plot works against it throughout. Also the so called "realism" leaves alot to be desired.
Good movie, alittle slow in the beginning but the real action begins as the movie goes on. Would recommend if you like police action.

Writer/Director David Ayer, who has made a cottage industry in the police thriller genre, brings nothing new to the table in this meandering cinematic wreck.  Jake Gyllenhall and Michael Pena are introduced right off the bat as LAPD patrol officers in the mold of countless other big-screen cops: They play by their own rules, they ignore their superiors but they get results, etc., etc.  The duo are also presented as good friends and partners, but that's the first of the film's many problems: This deep, important friendship that should form the core of the film is simply established as if it were some immutable law of nature, with no real explanation of why they care for one another so much or how their partnership came to be.

After running afoul of a Mexican cartel's operations in South Central, the duo finds their lives in danger - but only for the last 15 or 20 minutes of the film.  The rest is largely plotless, covering the officers' daily patrols over the course of an indeterminate period of time and the constantly escalating horrors they face on the job.  This shouldn't be a problem, as procedurals and thrillers have used the mundane details of life on the beat to great effect, but here nothing comes together or has any weight until the film suddenly begins moving toward its clunky resolution.  Before that point, though, Ayers throws in a lot of typical cop drama scenes about the partners idly chatting about their lives, but the script never takes them any deeper than "This job is dangerous" and "I want to have a family some day."

It should also be noted that a "found footage" conceit is established early, and ignored for the rest of the film.  Ayers goes to lengths to show that Gyllenhall and Pena are equipped with cameras as part of Gyllenhall's college art class (A paper-thin justification which is never mentioned again,) but the majority of the film is shot via non-diagetic sources.  By the end of the film the only reason the cameras seem to be there are to give other officers another thing to reprimand them for.  I can't count the number of times another officer tells the heroes to turn off their cameras.

Anna Kendrick shines as a Prop - it's difficult to call her a character, given her tiny amount of screen time and lack of real personality - introduced for no discernible reason other than to reenforce the heterosexuality of Jake Gyllenhall's character.  (The male leads say "I love you" to one another far more than they do their respective romantic interests, ostensibly to show how deep their on the job partnership is.  One senses the studio got cold feet about people potentially misinterpreting that.)  Natalie Martinez, playing the wife of Pena's character, is given even less to work with and makes even less of an impression (Save for one enjoyable scene where she is given a chance to actually do something on camera other than look worried.)

I can't stress it enough - "End of Watch" is a mess of a movie.  Avoid.
It was a great movie from start to end. Enjoyed the story as much as the action. The final gun battle at the end is not to be missed!!

Jake Gyllenhaal and Michael Pea are absolutely fantastic in this movie! I ordered it based on the trailer and my girlfriend's iron fist but even then, my expectations were not that high. You will NOT be disappointed. This is not your run of the mill two cops with exaggerated force credentials running through the streets of Los Angeles crime stopping - this story is very much believable and the ending is truly amazing and not as predictable as, let's say, "Taken 2" *snore*... Go ahead and order this movie! You'll be engaged throughout, many will laugh and some may even cry but when the credits roll, you will not be asking for your money back.

I can't think of a single person I know who wouldn't love this movie.  I don't want to add any spoilers but please spend the money to rent it at least.  This is a movie I will absolutely purchase now that I have seen it, in fact I will be watching it again with my mom, I watch A LOT of movies and rarely do I find one that I want to watch again the next day, it hasn't happened since Kill Bill.  Gyllenhaal & Pena were the best I have ever seen them, they make their relationship 100% believable, one of the few movies I have watched where I forget I am watching a movie and buy into the plot like it's actually happening in front of me.  The supporting actors were also believable in their roles.  I think twice about renting movies highly rated by film critics (as I usually disagree with the majority of what most of them have to say) but they were spot on with this film, it is a must see.  I will add that it is deserving of it's R rating for violence and language, they didn't have to pump this movie up with too many over done, out of place sex scenes, instead it focuses more on good solid relationships between partners and their cop brothers as well as their own families, and the conflicts of being an officer and what our police officers get at home when they put their lives on the line to save civilians.  Best movie I have seen that was released in 2012.
It was a typical but realistic police movie. It showed you the good sides,the bad sides and everything in between. This movie was as current to what goes on in the streets as one could get.

The chemistry between the Jake Gyllenhaal and Michael Pea was nothing short of amazing.  I felt like they knew each other for years.  The directing, the script, it all was amazing. This is THE classic cop movie. This movie has been long over due. Character development in this movie is second to none. Two funny bastards (Jake Gyllenhaal and Micheal Pena) face off against the evils of Los Angeles. You get a legitimate version of the world from their perspective. The director is true to the locker room antics and rough housing we all appreciate at men (and a few women). This movie is aimed pretty squarely at the action loving guy humor crowed. Although this movie isn't anything like Lethal Weapon. I imagine if you liked Lethal Weapon, you would like this movie. I wouldn't recommend it for kids, (Dismembered bodies). Like my review it it helped.

The movie was realistic, but kept changing dates so you had to watch carefully to keep up with what segment of time you were in.

Though both major actors in this movie are extremely talented and worth watching in just about everything I have seen them in, this movie is most certainly a smudge on the "resume" of both actors. The movie may have been made by the same people that brought us Training Day but there is no comparison as to the quality of the movies.
This movie is seemingly a rah rah propaganda piece on the selfless all giving that police officers all supposedly lay on the line to help keep us all safe and secure. Reality is a different story. Police officers are nothing more than after the fact data collection clerks. There are VERY few crimes that police personnel prevent, very few. Mop up is about all they do and they get paid way too much for what they do. Are there casualties? Certainly. The same can be said for every other public employee involved in any physical activity. Garbagemen get injured far more frequently than police officers for example.
The majority of a police officers time is involved in the very dangerous intervention in domestic disputes. That is one "plus" that the police are indeed needed for. Far too often policemens duty involves drug related offenses. These are generally victimless crimes, and yes I know the general retort about the damage done to the user. That is what God called "free will". The ongoing and never ending "war on drugs" has caused far more physical and property damage than the effects of the gamut of drugs out there ever would have.
Do I feel sorry for police officers? Not at all. They made the choice when they applied. Many applicants can do little else that pays anywhere near what a policemans salary does. Far too many police officers abuse the power granted to them. Abuses which are very seldom addressed. When was the last time you heard of a policeman actually being punished for a "questionable use of force"? Rarely.
This movie is another flick shot by way of the "Blair Witch Method". PLEASE, lay off the hand held amatuerish technique. It is overused and covers a lack of real film making technique.
Didnt like the movie at all, have no sympathy for police officers and would really like to return to the days when directors really had to do their job. Enough already with the shaky, handheld video B.S.. Also, please give some thought to saving some of the billions this country annually spends on the failed war on drugs. Prohibition in any form will never work and only serves to provide employment to people that would otherwise have to learn a useful skill to earn a living.

Not a real cop, but did spend two years working with narcotics and gang cops in a bad part of town, had been there for chases, had a drive-by shooting happen right in front of me, etc. So, ya, it is exciting and heart-pumping at times. These are excellent actors. However, the supporting characters, which are often the best in movies, are paper thin and one-dimensional. The non-action scenes seem mostly contrived to get you to the next action scene. If you are an action junkie, and really don't care if a story has a strong narrative, rich plot development and that kind of thing, you are going to be happy. If you are expecting another Training Day with interesting characters throughout the movie, don't expect much. In fact, expect very little.

The story writing was strong in creating likeable characters out of two LAPD cops. This 'day in the life of story' has a lot of action and spends considerable time stressing thier friendship. However, the ending shows all of this to be a set-up to elicit an emotional response from the audience to an ending that would have been more interesting as the ending of the 2nd act and not the 3rd.

I'm a review reader. So of course, with the mixed feelings of people, I went into watching this flick not certain I would care for the film style. The beginning is a very fast cut (quick jumps from scene to scene) that can make your head swim a bit. I like this kind of cinematography but the first 5-10 minutes was extreme. Either I adapted or the editing slowed down.. after that time it didn't bother me.

Overall the movie was enjoyable. The comments about language: didn't phase me in this movie. The lack of plot: I don't agree. Its not deep by any stretch but I did feel the movie kept building. I guess what bothered me the most was the unrealistic camera angles thrown in. So both cops have a clip on cam, there is a handheld cam and the gang recorded its own footage. And somehow there was footage found from a Central American cartel. We'll even throw in the cruiser cam footage. So who filmed the rear of the vehicle and focused on the "Interceptor" emblem as both cops pulled up to a scene? This happens too many times during the movie (unrealistic angles) and it distracts from the found film genre that the movie was trying to achieve.

Overall, a watchable flick. 3.5 stars out of five. Its not epic. Its not deep. Its not a family film. Its raw and taps into that dark side of life. That alone makes it unique enough to watch.
This movie had a lot of action throughout and was very suspenseful. Started off a little weird with the first person camera angles but quickly got better.

Entertaining, action-packed and very real. Being from Los Angeles, we appreciated the authenticity of the LA crime scene. We actually watched the movie on the recommendation of several police officers who said they enjoyed it. The movie was funny, suspenseful and even a tear-jerker at times. Definitely worth watching.

This is one of the best movies I've ever seen. The way it was filmed is unique - I have not seen a movie filmed from so many angles and vantage points. The movie is raw, humorous, realistic, and very human. The crew and the actors did a super job making this film. I can't say enough great things about this movie. It also pays tribute to the Police Officers who maintain order and work to keep us safe. I'm very glad I now own this film. If you liked the films "Training Day" and "Harsh Times" I think you'll also enjoy this one. Great stuff!

Short and Sweet: Well directed film with more than competent writing and support cast. The cinematography is terrific and, thankfully, the film isn't overly wedded to POV shots even though one of the characters carries a hand-held camera everywhere he goes. Still, cop movies come a dime a dozen, and it's an easy genre in which to produce a lesser work because of the temptation to fill up gaps with action scenes and (over the last three decades or so) a stream of profanity that would make most of the principals in The Aristocrats blush. Thankfully, both of these things are present in abundance in this film, yet what rescues it from becoming still another flashy but ultimately vacuous gritty-in-your-face-yet-diversity-sensitive-ethnic-mash-up-So Cal cop drama is the decision to focus on the relationship between the two cops rather than on the plot. What makes that decision work is the stellar chemistry between Gyllenhaal and Pena. I can't praise their work here enough; there is hardly a scene in the film with one of them that doesn't have the other in it, so their relationship had to be believable. I would, in fact, go so far as to say that the film is worth seeing (and, ultimately, studying) just as an example of a film carried by the platonic, though profound, relationship between its two main characters.
End of Watch is an excellent cop thriller. Every cop should own this one. Funny, exciting, and sad. Can't ask for much more.
No one should watch this movie. poor acting bad language not much of a plot. Bad view always or most of the time looking from camera on person.

It was unfortunate that I missed seeing End of Watch in theaters, but even watching it on my laptop I couldn't believe how great the movie ended up being. The brotherly relationship of the two main character cops creates pathos and badly needed comic relief during the more intense parts of the movie. This movie is incredibly well put together abounding with foreshadowing, parallels, and other devices signature of a good movie.

Great movie, I highly recommend it!

This isn't your typical crime action movie.  The filming perspective is similar to the movie "Cloverfield" where the characters are doing the actual recording.  Where this can be a little hard to follow at times, it does add to the overall perception of the viewer.  The plot is good and the acting is good.  I'm glad that I bought it!

You totally believe the cops friendship and that you're getting a peak into real lives. The filming by Gyllenhaal's character is an interesting added element that added to the film without turning into a jerky, "found footage" kind of thing. If you like cop dramas, this should be satisfying.

I tend to prefer art house or foreign flicks to commercial ventures, but every now and then I'll foray into the land of Hollywood skin and excess. Glad I revisited my old haunts and took in this one - End of Watch - a well crafted, entertaining, steadily paced film which most probably reveals the challenges a street cop is up against when fighting drug crime in LA. Jake Gyllenhaal's and Michael Pena's bromance is witty and fun to watch and Anna Kendrick (from Up in the Air) as Jake Gyllenhaal's love interest doesn't disappoint. I'd definitely rent this one if you haven't seen it. Two thumbs up!

It makes the scenes a bit "rougher" and more dramatic.  If you're expecting a typical happy-go-lucky Hollywood movie, this isn't it.  But it will move you.
