I loved the chemistry among the actors. An intense story lightened with bits of humor. Intense, troubling, fascinating. Gyllenhaal s best suited to this type of role. While I'm not sure we can "enjoy" a movie of this sort, it was time well-spent and I am happy that I saw it.

I really loved this movie.  It was one of the better movies I have seen in a long time.  I liked the way it was shot documentary style because it caught a large range of emotions - some parts were funny  - some serious - some sickening - some suspenseful.  I also liked the flow between personal and professional lives and how it documented these 2 at a critical time in life when adults struggle to both establish themselves professionally and settle down personally.  I will probably watch it again.

Great, realistic flick! Language is over the top and the first ten minutes will turn most people off.  But this is the world that cops all over the world live in.  The 'average' person doesn't get it because the 'average' person doesn't hang out with people that talk and act the way that the the people do that cops interact with on a daily basis.  Think about it - whens the last time you saw a cop in your neighborhood?  If you don't know that tells you, you don't actually no what crime and stupidity are because you're isolated and don't actually see it or probably even know about it.
The story and acting was great. The video was atrocious. I know they were trying to get the home video effect going but it just ruined the whole movie. It was like watching a bad episode of COPS
This is the best cop movie ever! when i saw it in theater i couldn't wait for it to come out on amazon instant its my favorite movie!
I have no further comment and hate that you make me do this when all I want is to watch

I gave this movie 4 stars it was very good and entertaining but could be jumpy at times. The one police officer was filming with his video camera so it looked jumpy at times. This movie was good in that it made you feel like you were with them routine police work and dangerous times as well. You could see how dangerous it is to be a police officer every day never knowing what your walking into on any given day.
I worked 23 years as a street cop.  Then went to a college and taught Criminal Justice for another 15.  Great cop flick.  Real police fans will like the movie.

Gritty with a mix of traditional and first person style footage.  This actually works and does not distract from the overall plot and feel.  Excellent performances, especially from Michael Pena, he is very underrated as an actor. Solid entertainment.

this movie is awseome it really shows the brother hood between 2 cops. plus there is alot of action so that is good 2. but the ending of the movie really sucks and i wish they did not make it end they why they did
Not sure if my expectations for this movie was too low, but this is the best movie I have seen in a while...
Seriously. This movie. The way it's shot is incredible and the acting is insanely believable. It's like if you and your best mate were cops chatting it up on the job. Absolutely incredible movie.
I really like the plot and the characters of the movie. Lots of good action and some character development. Worth the cost of the rental in my opinion
Don't expect all to end well, it's a story with a lesson about service and friends. Great cast, comes off as real to life but only close in some aspects. I would watch it again, it's that good.
I would recommend this movie. Great action/ cop movie. Will keep you on the edge of your seat. You will enjoy this movie.

This is an entertaining movie of two hot shot officers finding opportunities to be hero's.  In the end, the hero lives as usual.
The movie is not overly realistic of every day police work but does depict the dangers officers can face at the drop of a hat.
This movie was fantastic and kept me glued to the screen with all the action. I would certainly recommend this to you!

Excellent script and solid believable  performance from the amazing cast, make a gripping and surprisingly touching movie of loyalty courage and love.  It is at turns extremely humorous and sometimes crushing, it follows two individuals working at the toughest face of a broken society in a job whose daily challenges we can only begin to imagine as it hurtles toward the most powerful ending I have seen in a movie in a very long time..
I gained so much respect for our men in blue. I can't stop thinking about them. Makes me want to hug the next cop I see.
watch it already, you know its going to be good, just do it already! and its really good so youll like it
If you enjoyed Training Day like I did then this movie is a must see.  Gives you more thoughts about what really happens with the drug cartels controlling our country.
The movie was good but I wasn't a huge fan of the ending. But everything up until then was really entertaining.
This film was much better than I anticipated. Shot with multiple cameras, fast paced. I would recommend this to anyone who enjoys this genre.
This had: action, emotion and suspense.  Seemed pretty realistic.  Probably a bit too bloody for most of the girls, but my wife managed to get through it.

Nothing novel in the plot but the director shows great poise in handling the screen play that manages to glue the viewer to the narrative.

One would walk away wondering if there could have been more in terms of pure creative input towards the end of the movie. All in all , it is a decent watch.
Movie was better than I expected and a great addition to the action genre.  Not as good as Training Day but a good cop movie for sure.

I live in L.A and grew up around real gangsters.  That does not make me special but what it does allow me to do is know when a movie seems legit.  This movie was legit.  Some of the scenes are way out and unbelieveable but still a great movie.  Takes you from adrenalin Rush to sadness to laughter.  I dug it.

I found this movie to be like you are a ride along passenger watching real events unfold as they happen. Great character chemistry, pretty good storyline and the ending caught me a little surprised. (that is getting harder to do as years go by!)
If you like just raw everyday street cop stories, you will like watching this one.

I had no idea what I'd be watching when I saw this movie (a friend recommended it), I just knew it was about police. We had to overlook all the errors and "Yeah, right." moments, but I really liked the show until the end - when I thought we still had an hour left and it was over!

There was the start of a big, involved storyline when the partners  stumbled upon a human trafficking/drug cartel("Follow me through the door.") which I expected to dominate the last half of the movie.  However, it just kinda disappeared and life went on.  Or maybe I missed something?  Pretty sure I didn't fall asleep.  Anyway, that storyline never really went anywhere and next thing you know, the movie's over.  Left me confused and unsatisfied, and looking incredulously at my watch.

I also found the woman gang-banger unbelievable. She seemed like an actress who would belong more on a TV sitcom or chick flick than in this kind of role. Maybe the gang-bangers had something to do with the cartel but it just wasn't enough. It could have been so much more indepth and intense.

Bottom line is that I quite liked the movie, as it developed, but was very disappointed when it really didn't go anywhere.  I felt cheated by the cop-out ending. (pun intended!)

Great movie! The relationship between the main characters is very believable and nicely orchestrated. It's very captivating and full of surprises.  If your worried that it's "just another cop movie" - I suggest you give it a chance - you'll be glad you did! It's hard to be specific without giving too much away - but the performances will stir emotions for sure!

Lots of plot holes and questions that left someone looking for a more layered movie a bit disappointed. Acting is phenomenal and the chemistry of all the actors, especially Gyllenhall and Pena, is top notch. The supporting roles are also very good.  There were just parts that didn't make complete sense, and i felt like it decreased the quality of the movie.  Overall, the action and the acting make it very compelling, but this seems like the kind of movie people will either love or hate.
What a movie this was one of the best buddy cop movies ever made jake gyn and mike Pena did their thing it was expertly written and was exciting from start to finish one of the best movies for 2012
Really enjoyed this movie. One of the better ones to come out of Hollywood in a long time.  Would recommend buying DVD for collection.
Jake Gyllenhaalj and Michael Pea did a very good job. The script was AWLFUL! The writers used the F bomb as if it was its own form of language.  A shame to waste the talents of these actors.
Filmed as a documentary which was kind of strange.  Good plot though and kind of graphic - used the "F" word too much.

Poorly done and excessive POV shooting from cops side, enemy side, random locations...etc, was too much, and very unrealistic. Would bad guys really film themselves plotting to murder cops?  What happens if they lose the tape? Would good officers in the field really focus more on wanting to capture footage, even while under fire, than on doing their job professionally or save their lives? Additionally, from a cinematic standpoint, the angles were poorly done and distracting to watch over time and, again, took away from what would have been an above average movie. This movie is nothing like the masterpiece, 'Training Day,' so if you were expecting an equal to that, you will be disappointed.

On another note, the directors sadly chose to make the two lead characters all-in-one heroes, even when it totally undermines the credibility of the film. Our two protagonist fill the duties of firefighters, street cops, and detectives/special agents all rolled into one. In fact, so good are they, they can go into a fully involved house without PPE and survive the temperatures and gases that would kill in seconds anyone else. They also perform casing/stakeout operations without warrants or backup. This film, unfortunately, was too much, too poory filmed to live up to the high expectations I had for it....

I enjoyed this film. Two thumbs up.  It helped turn a boring evening into a decent night.  standard def looks so good on 1080p tv.  $3.99 is easy for a new release.  No driving, standing in line or movie to return. 48 hour rental is always nice.
this movie brings fire to the screen. Just wish they had made the ending last longer. I had to watch the movie twice to get a clear understanding.

Poignant Story with real characters undergoing real challenges and dealing with them in realistic ways (for the most part).  Major and only downfall is gratuitous use of the "F" word - borderline Guiness Book.  But if you can get through that, you have a memorable story and hope it's not the last installment.

This film is perfectly casted, thoughtfully scripted and pays attention to the real world. They cared enough to have an adviser who obviously understands being on the street. The realistically long periods of inaction in the cruiser were filled with some of the best buddy dialogue to ever hit the screen. A great story has been told!

Loved this movie! I rarely give five stars to any movie, but this one definitely deserved them all.

I usually can't stand cop and robber movies because Hollywood makes them so unrealistic and just plain stupid. I used to be a cop myself, and while I never saw the kind of action that cops see almost on a daily basis in that part of California, I found this movie to be believable in practically every scene.

This movie was so intense that I felt "disturbed" when it was over. That hardly ever happens to me after watching a flick.

I definitely recommend anyone above 16 to watch this. It's definitely not for the little ones. In fact, you may just want to buy it and add it to your library. I plan to!
Great movie!  Held my attention the entire time and had a great story.  I would definitely recommend the movie to others.

This movie was very gruesome and hard to watch. I don't like violent movies but my husband really wanted to watch it. Acting is good I thought and the way they made the movie look realistic is fantastic. I think that's why for me (a softy) this movie was so hard to watch.
Great movie but the end is dissappointing. good acting and I liked the home movie feel but it was a little nauseating at times

This movie was awesome...the last scene was kind of a random add-on that could've been tied in to the movie or left out all together, but overall this was a great movie and worth watching.  Would definitely recommend it.
Too violent to continue story, especially when I didn't care about the characters.  I do not recommend it.  That's all!

Was bored on a Sunday looking for a movie with some action, a decent plot line, and that didn't require a whole lot of thought. End of Watch exceeded those expectations by a fair margin.  The relationship between the two main characters develops throughout the movie and caring about them and their families draws you in and adds quite a bit of drama to the overall plot. Not the greatest movie I've ever seen in my life, but well worth watching.
Good movie, but the story line was incomplete.  However, I can't say more without giving away the plot.  Watch the movie and decide for yourself.
We thought this was a pretty good movie, not quite what we expected. Enjoyed watching, was not too enthused about the camera documentary style though

Not much plot, just two cops who have really bonded going about their business, packing more tense situations into a couple of hours than most cops experience in two lifetimes.  Good likable cast.  Great, palm-sweating escape.

I should have turned this movie off in the first 2 minutes.  Don't spend money on it.  Probably one of the worst movies I have ever seen.  Seriously, I am a grown man and can handle plenty of crudeness, but this movie must have said the F*$% word every 2-3 seconds, it was annoying to listen to and I felt like I had spent 2 hours degrading myself.
This is just a great film. Love the "found footage," style.  I feel like this film accuratley portrays life as a LAPD officer.

In some ways this is not an easy movie to watch because there is a lot of violence.  However, the characters are well-developed and there are light moments.  It is very entertaining, well-acted and well-written.
The movie provides an insight to the realities those in uniform face  daily. I pray for all those that wear a uniform and risk their life to keep us safe.
After watching, my only thought was "Can I get my $3.99 back?" All the best parts of the movie are in the trailer.
Good story without going over the top. Well acted. Good believable plot. Story moves right along. I recommend this movie.

Truly an outstanding film. I applaud those that serve the military and local law enforcement. These people give so much so we can live our lives in freedom and keep our families protected from the scumbags. This film shows us that police officers have lives too. Remember this film if you ever get pulled over for a minor driving violation. Just admit your mistake and remember to say "Thank You".
Great movie, makes you think twice about what our law enforcement put up with and we should be greatful. A story of brotherhood, where you would lay down your life for your brother.

This was a real edge of your seat thriller. The filming format and story reminded me a lot of the T.V. show, Southland- (a favorite on my TV lineup.)
I haven't liked many movies that came out this year, but this one is a five star in my opinion!

loved it, gripping, just like the real thing from a former LAPD.
My iwfe and I both cried it was beautiful, I cant wait for a sequel!
Overall I enjoyed the movie. This is at least worth a Rental. I used Amazon's Instant movie rental and this was very easy and the HD played very well on my player and 12Mbit download.

This film was great from start to finish. Non stop action and a great story line. I could not guess the ending and was different than expected a must see for those who like action this will do the trick.
While this movie was not what I thought it would be. After watching it a second time, I picked up on some things I missed the first time and liked it a lot more.
I am in law enforcement and have been a cop (admittedly not in la) and the action is a little exagerated. But it is a good movie anyway.

Let me start off by saying I am cop wife, so this movie hit a little to close to home. This is the most realistic cop movie I have ever seen. I rented it and then went and bought it. I loved it! And my husband the cop loved it!

This is a very realistic look into the life of a cop on a beat.  The story line doesn't feel the least far fetched, considering the reach and power of today's drug cartels.  It is quite believable that a cop can find themselves in way too deep.  Excellent performances by all the cast.  I'll probably have to view it one more time to make sure I didn't miss any details.
Very suspenseful, hilarious and well depicted in relationships.  Great acting of the two main stars!  I would recommend to friends.
This movie was very well done. There was a lot of suspense and I wanted to know what was going to happen to the characters in the film. I would recommend it to anyone who enjoys action movies.
I haven't seen a movie that depicted south central like this since Boyz N the Hood. Great chemistry between Pena and Gyllenhaal.

Ok, but I expected more action and more from both of these actors but the script just flip flopped from personal to action, back to personal...  Expected something similar to Colors or Training Day but no where near as good.
My husband is a law in force man.  My son and my Husband LOVE IT.  Its a must see picture.
We laughed, we cried and we sat on the edge of the couch in suspense. Great movie and would watch it again. Different style of movie which reminded me of oliver stone's greatest movies.
A good flick that kept me engaged.  I enjoyed the brotherly relationship story between Jake Gyllenhaal and Michael Pena's characters.

Action movie and entertaining. Don't judge the movie from the Trailer, the movie and the ending is not what you expect.

Would recommend it to anyone.
Good movie, filming style made me car sick. Like the blair witch movie. 4 out of 5 given for this movie.
Excellent movie, great entertainment but obviously not for the faint of heart - Jake and his partner both do tremendous jobs.

It dragged on a little too long, but is definitely worth watching.  It gives the viewer an appreciation for the different scenarios and dangerous situations police offers, particularly in LA are put in.
The story was good and the acting was great. But the camera was too shaky about 85% of the time. At times it felt like a long episode of the show COPS. But other than that, I really liked it.
I know it was a real life picture of police work in east LA, but after 15 minutes of it, I'd had enough.
This show was horrible , trying to show the life of two cops doing impossible things. my whole family are police and they also thought the movie was a joke. save your money this was a joke.
This was a waste of time no plot and too much profanity. the opening cjade screen was the best part of this whole movie.

Another movie filmed in the amateur, "found footage" style. I was able to get through "Chronicle" and "Project X" with the shaky hand held style but a police movie? I watched the movie twice because the amateur style is so distracting. If this movie was filmed in the regular way I would give it 5 stars. Excellent cast (look for Ugly Betty!), very tense moments dealing with criminals and a really good final 15 minutes or so. Very violent and loaded with profanity. The F word is used around 350 times. I have a new respect for urban Police Officers.

End of Watch was excellent movie. I liked the whole cameraesk video taping the life of a South Central LA PD officer. Jake Gyllenhaal and Michael Pena play a tight nit officers that are after more then just regular police work - they put their lives on the line everyday to protect and serve the black and white!!!
Keeps you on the edge of your seat, from start to finish. One of the best movies of the year, great acting from the whole cast.
Got my heart going for sure, very happy we rented this and enjoyed the story line. The "heroes" weren't your everyday good guys, they were kind of like ... losers, haha.

This movie was a little "too real" being an LEO's wife.  I love that they actually made the cops the "good guys" instead of dirty/crooked cops.  It runs the gamut of emotions - made me laugh, cry, was exciting & suspenseful.  I would recommend to anyone, but if you're offended by bad language it's not for you.  They probably over did it with the profanity; it's riddled with it.
This movie wasn't half as good as training day. It's characters were just not compelling. My wife and I were happy when it ended.

Terrible!

Boring.

Stupid.

Sad to have actually spent money on this movie! BOMB. What was I thinking? JUST SAY NO
I thought it was a movie that everyone would have enjoyed even more if the camera angles were more steady ... Story was good and acting was well done. .. Over all , im glad I saw it.
Good mix between comedy, action and drama. First movie I rented from Amazon for my iPad, worked very well on it

First off, the movie is filmed like its a reality show.  Think Paranormal Activity.  I found his very annoying.  The previews all touted, from the makers of Training Day.  I really liked Training Day, and this is not in Training Day's league.  The story is simplistic and disjointed with an unsatisfactory ending.  I hoped for more from this movie and it was consistently disappointing.
This movie was full of heart, love and many very intense scenes! I caught myself on the edge of my seat a few times!  5 stars, loved and recommend this movie!!!!
This was a great movie, definitely action packed!  It was like the movie Traffic meets Crash meets Training Day...if you liked those films, you'll love this one too.
Excellent film. The cast and script both first rate. I am surprised this film did not receive more attention as it is better than many splashier productions.

Great movie to stay at home and watch on a sat night.
Funny and action the entire time and pretty real looking as well
Definitely a great movie.  Shocking and realistic.  Great camera angles and story telling.  Both lead actors bring new life to law enforcement acting and believable.

The only reason I gave it one star is because I couldn't rate it lower.  This must be a critically acclaimed "film" because it's definitely a poorly written and directed attempt at a movie. It is slow developing and drags on and on. If your idea of a good movie is watching 2 guys ride around in a car, throw in a little action and have every other word throughout the whole movie being "F" this or "MF" this, then this is the movie for you.  Otherwise don't waste your time.

What a terrific movie.

I was expecting the guy humor.  I was also expecting action and tense situations.

My expectations were met 100%.

What I didn't expect, that exceeded expectations...

- Some of the deeper thematic elements, like the bond formed between people that entrust one another with their lives.  But, more than that, the bond between their families...the sense of extended family between officers.
- The on-screen dynamics between the lead actors.
- The insight into what being a cop can be like.  Makes me thankful that people out there give of themselves to perform this function.
- I wasn't expecting the sadder elements...the sense of loss...the tough situations.  Very dramatic and something easily realistic.

OVERALL - Great movie!

End Of Watch is one of the most compelling Cop Dramas in years. Told without the usual Hollywood fanfare and formulas. we're pulled inside the multi faceted lives of two officers, partners in the war against unspeakable crime in South Central LA -and pulled deeper my the moment into the extraordinary friendship of two partners who become Brothers in Arms in every sense of the word.

I was a huge fan of Training Day and although the style at times reflect the filmmakers style don't expect the "action' not the story to be anything like it. Yes, there's violence here - but it's realism and the mere peek of it is never gratuitous but essential. It's the raging fire in which a bond is forged and the fate of a friendship forever forged.

Jake Gyllenhall and Michael Pena are sensational on screen and both have shown unexpected an most welcome acting chops - the scenes between them range from high energy funny to gutting intensity. Dialogue is fast and electric, it's raw and it's real. As for the supporting cast there's not one hollow performance the entire cast must have known or felt this project was special - and special it is.

There are no bad cops here and no super heroes, just men and women who represent the finest of a police force that sees more human devastation in a single day then most of their brothers and sisters in other parts of the country will see in the summation of their entire career. The film knows this but it doesn't grandstand it simply play homage and respect to all those in uniform for the right reasons and who's personal sense of honor is palatable throughout the entire film.

A marvelous example of smart story telling and brilliant movie making - End Of Watch - should not be missed.
Awesome movie  best I have seen since Lawless  Too many characters required to just say you liked the movie?  this is why i don't rate products.
A very realistic cop movie. Jake Gyllenhaal was excellent as well Michael Pena.  I thoroughly enjoyed watching it and recommend it 100%!!!!!
I loved this movie! Finally something refreshing and new. Michael Pena is definitely one of my favorite actors. He didn't disappoint in this movie either.
Maybe one of the best films I've ever seen, certainly in the top 3 of this year.  You won't regret renting it.
never expected the ending I couldn't help but cry at the end with one dead and the other attempting to protect him even in death
A very good police crime story, this DVD has excellent sound and a very good picture quality, I am very glad I purchased it
Good performances, scary look into the war zones cops face here at home. Depressing, yet uplifting at the same time
I only like to see highly rated movies and was not disappointed. Action with a believable story line is combined with reality like filming.

End of Watch is a pretty good movie.  The end is a bummer, but it is a cop movie- what to you expect?  However, hubby did wish there was a little more action, or "fighting," in the movie and expressed his disappointment quite a bit.
Awesome movie. Must see, I never get tire of watching this movie. Everyone in this movie is a great actor
Lethal weapon meets the blair witch project.. Good performances can't save this unbelievable plot and predictable climax. Skip it and watch something else

Completely original? No. Plenty of movies out there about police officers and tales of their struggles with the rigors of the job. But this movie hit the mark. Much like training day I like the true to life form of the movie. Anyone that was born in the City of Angles (like myself) will be able to relate to this movie. Even those born elsewhere will get a glimpse of life in a major US city that deals with daily gang violence and lives of the people that attempt to contain the madness.
The movie was intense throughout while delivering some genuine emotions (funny, witty, caring, sadness). Definitely not for family members of law enforcement. Tear jerker for you.
Very gritty, fast paced movie. The two actors are believable as cops in what is a s***ty part of L.A. Worth watching for sure a lot of good action.
Fantastic movie!! Has a great story line and was able to capture the realism not found in most police movies. Will watch again and recommend to friends.
Glad I did not view this in a theater. Really drug along in some places I thought and really just not a movie you would want to watch more than once.
Fantastic acting and action scenes.  Hard to pause it when you need to.  I'm gonna buy this DVD. Gyllenhaal and Pena rocked.
Takes you for a satisfying emotional roller coaster! Get ready for some serious tears, some serious laughter, and some serious heart soaring.

Personally I thought this was drivel, the dialogue is laughable, bad guys/girls are hams - Jake Gyllenhaal is, as usual, good, but he can't save it. Officer III (a rank just below Sergeant it seems) goes off on some anal sex rant to which the correct response would be "are you having mental problems?" and to get him back on his meds pretty quick. It takes a seriously strong stomach to handle the little speech Gyllenhaal is saddled with as the movie opens - I can paraphrase it as "cops are the most amazing people in the world and also a bit like Terminators". Yes... well... kinda clashes with the later sentiment (borrowed from Southland) that its the only way someone with no real education can earn a half decent wage. The moron who wrote this knows the world through TV and movies and, in my opinion, have never actually been out in it. Lame.

This movie is filled with about a million F-bomb's and too much blood and gore. Story line would make for a good movie but got tired quickly of the language. Trailers didn't capture the carnage depicted in the movie.

If you can get past the shaky-documentary camera treatment -- which is authentic but sometimes annoying -- this is a well-done story of two beat cops in south-central L.A. whose trust and love for each other relationship fuel their effectiveness and risk-taking on the job. Jake Gyllenhaal was good but the under-rated Michael Pena gave an outstanding performance.
This is not your average cop story, it has a very realistic, very human feel to it.  The ending has a twist so..... Pay attention

I didn't object to the gritty story or the requisite violence, but I was not happy with the jerky, hand-held cinema verite camera style. The older I get, the more that gives me a headache. Gyllenhaal's performance was adequate, and Michael Pena was excellent. The most objectionable part of the film was the long sequence toward the end that was outrageously unrealistic.
Really makes you feel like your watching a documentary.  I felt like I was in the car with them.  A must watch.

This movie is very, very long. There is a lot of character development, but no actual story and for some reason EVERYONE in the film is recording themselves. There is a good bromance vibe and some great one-liners, but it's wasted because there is no point - have I mentioned there is no point to this movie? There is no point. There are several almost points: a rookie, a bitter old cop, human trafficking, a romance, the Mexican cartel, and a mysterious commando team who might be interesting.

Don't waste your money or your time: you've always wanted to learn to play guitar, right? Work on that tonight, instead.
Sheepdogs we are. Everyday is never the same. Every member is family. Great movie. Are we that cocky though? LOL
sensitive, keeps your attention and lots of action, sad ending.  Makes you appreciate the police and their families sacrifies made
The movie was great.  The actors really portray the b.s. nonsense, the violence and camaraderie that makes a shift go by.  My hats off to the director and actors.

Two good actors put in a bad movie. this entire movie was shot with a video camera . Shaking the camera when a fight broke out just gave me a headache. The script was poor as well. This movie should have stated it was to be filmed by the actors video camera in which a documentary was being made. very boring to watch-music was horrible also.
I thought the movie was great but the quality was grainy to start and reset my Roku a couple of times.
Wanted to like it but the story was just too predictable and the links with the cartel were poorly done.

Terrible movie. It stalled and skipped to the point where we couldn't watch it. I hope amazon refunds our money or I will never rent another movie from them. I have rented movies from other vendors without any problems.End of Watch
Really enjoyed this movie.  If you know someone in law enforcement or you are in law enforcement, then you will enjoy this movie.

I just watched this and let me say it was amazing.  First let me start by saying my idea of a good movie is on that evokes emotion and this does!  It's like a non-stop action thrill ride that takes you from shooting down bad guys to serious tragedy.  It really makes you think about all the hard working cops protecting us and our cities around the world.  If you're still trying to decide if you should watch this or not, just watch it and decide after the movie.

Enjoy the show!

This movie showed the array of challenges faced by those who protect us, and how their actions put them in harm's way. Protecting our protectors is one of the most important questions in society, without that we have anarchy.

I cannot believe this is not in the Oscar nominations, it's the most convincing movie I've seen for a long time. Wonderfully acted, wonderfully scoped, but maybe hard to watch

There was no actual plot to the story/movie.  There was some fun moments.  Even some moments where it catches your intentions and emotions, BUT... as a whole, it was a ok movie.  What I do like about this movie is how different it is compared to others in this genre.  It brings you down to the 'human-side' of officers and that they are just like average people, but in a difficult position of "profession".  Another thing I like (and a bit dislike I might add) is the camera angles throughout the movie. Some where fun and interesting seeing where and what the director was going for (and why).

Overall I'll give this a 7.5 out of ten. A nice rental.
Best movie I have seen in months...Its a sleeper watched 6 times this week  gave it 5 stars you laugh ,cry and feel like you know these everyday guys.

The movie does a decent job at capturing the life of an LA cop but really lacks in plot direction.  Feels like the movie is a bunch of scenes pulled together that lacks a fluid story line.  One scene is showing some funny banter between the two leads, next scene has some action, next scene shows a family engagement, etc, etc...

Very obvious.  Weak ending.

Considering the raving reviews, and not just from critics, I went into this movie with high expectations, AND I wanted to like it. I really enjoyed Training Day, which director, David Ayer produced. So I figured End of Watch was going to be of the same ilk. Not so. Let's count 'em down:

1. PRESENTATION: While the whole shaky camera thing was effective in some parts and quite nifty in others, on the whole, it became rather annoying, especially during the fight scenes. I mean, really? Someone in a brutal fight was holding a camera? I know that if I was in one of those confrontations, I would want BOTH of my hands. Just sayin'!

2. DIRECTION: Considering the use of documentary-style filming, it was done quite well; cameras were literally everywhere. It must have been quite an uptaking for the editing department. Even though Mr. Ayer wrote the script, he didn't give himself much to work with. It took a long time before I could determine where the story was going ... close to 45 minutes. That's almost half the movie--ridiculous.

3. ACTING: As everyone has noted in other reviews, the camaraderie and chemistry of the two leads was exceptional, some of it a bit tongue-in-cheek and ambiguous, but exceptional, nonetheless. The cartel members, especially "Bad Evil" and his girlfriend were WAY over-the-top with WAY too much overplay. I have been around people like that, and no one, NO ONE, says the F-Bomb that frequently. Sure, it comes up, but not with every other word as depicted here. The only time I have truly witnessed that type of repetitiveness concerning profane words in a purposeful situation was at a George Carlin concert back in the '80s.

4. STORY: Weak, at best. As already alluded to, the story really didn't get going until the middle of Act 2. There was simply way to much time focused on back-story. It could have been presented in such a way that would speed up the whole "get the audience to care about these characters" process. That would have freed up more time to allow a more expansive focus on the primary narrative.

5. OVERALL: Overrated. This movie is on par with being nothing more than a good episode of Southland. It is on par with every other ho-hum, so-so cop movie. Not bad, but not great. I liked some parts, and I had to suspend my belief system for others. It is a parity, but not (thank goodness) a parody.

I was fighting with myself throughout the entire movie on whether I liked it or not. I really did want to like it. Especially after watching the trailers and reading the reviews on it. I ended up being impatient and rented it as opposed to buying it. I planned to buy it later if I enjoyed it. After watching it, I will be waiting for a good sale to buy it. But I must say, a lot of the appeal for me is the fact that it is a police movie.

While the camera was kind of annoying at times, I wouldn't say that's a major gripe of mine. But some of the camera angles were annoying because of the way it was supposedly shot. It should have been done differently, and the reason for it was pretty ridiculous. I like the in car cameras, but the handheld camera in one of the fights scenes is ridiculous. But it wasn't so bad I wanted to turn off the movie.

I did really like the main actors. They did a great job at their parts, but I really do feel like some of the parts were "over-acted". There was mainly one part that I wanted to say "really....?" because every other word he said was the f-bomb. I have no problem with cussing in movies, but it becomes corny when they overuse it. That, on top of them trying to hard to personify the stereotypical police officer, are the reason I would say some parts were over-acted.

My last gripe would be..... I guess time management. It seems like they spent a lot of time on the back story. Mind you, I love movies where they really want you to care about the character, so they use back story. Then, if in danger, you are really pulling for them. While they did succeed at this, they overdid it. They did a good job at establishing the fact that these guys were like brothers, loved their significant others, etc... But they overdid it in the sense that there was a lot of scenes in the car where there would be sort of pointless chat that does nothing but keep the story from progressing. It goes from story building, to just spinning it's wheels. They just needed to get to the plot sooner. Once the movie gets to the point, you sort of say to yourself "ah.... so this is what the conflict in the movie is."

With all of that being said, the movie really does pick up in the second half. I just wish they would have focused more on the conflict, versus pushing the fact that we needed to realize these guys were like brothers. If the first half was more story oriented like the second, I would probably give it five stars. It just seemed like in the grand scheme of things, some of the first half was unnecessary. The second half is what I expected from the movie. The ending was also great. They did an awesome job of wrapping it up, and while the ending was unexpected, I'm glad they took the risk with it. Not only did it pay off, but realistically, that is the only way out of that whole situation. (minus backup showing up AFTER the fact...) This was definitely helped by some of the back story, but I feel like the same feelings towards the main characters would have still been there without as much random chatting. The last half of the movie could have actually been the entire movie. Mainly because there is some character building and character advancement, and then it gets to the main plot, conflict, and the ending. Had that been the movie, but more appropriately extended so it's more ''movie length'', it would have definitely been 5 stars.
Great acting!!!! Just like watching a documentary. A must see especially if you are a fan of crime/suspense. I was very surprised that the film did not get more critic appraise.

Hard-hitting, documentary-style realism, tight dialogue, technically sound, to-the-letter LAPD protocol and procedure, and a street gang element portrayed with frightening authenticity, make End of Watch one of the best cop films since Dennis Hopper's "Colors". Complimented by an equally strong wingman turn from Jake Gyllenhaal, this is Michael Pena's breakthrough performance. End of Watch gives new insight into life on the "thin blue line". A must-see, especially for cop movie fans.

I neither loved nor hated this film; it has decent moments of real emotion, some good shot composition, lots of action, and raises a number or questions worth asking. Gyllenhaal is as always solid, though he's kind of in his Jarhead mode here and was better in that, and Pena seems to play basically the same guy he plays in everything, not a whole lot of range. And the script, while occasionally funny and insightful, seems rather rote and nowhere near the writer's excellent Training Day.

But to top that off this BD has absolutely zero features, which a film like this could really benefit from. Discussions of the cartel problems in the USA that the corporate media almost never touches (ask yourself why), moral issues of the LAPD's history, and plenty of other topics could and should be addressed on commentaries and featurettes etc, as with almost all new blu-ray releases now. It's part of why they get away with charging so much for these discs which cost the same as dvds to make. So apart from a decent transfer here, why bother buying the BD? Just to see hacked up limbs in high def?

End of Watch (Two-Disc Combo Pack: Blu-ray + DVD + Digital Copy + UltraViolet) A great movie. I really enjoyed the movie. Good character development and back filling of the history between the two officers, our heroes, of the movie. While some might say that the movie plot is standard, perhaps so. But the telling of the story and how things progress had enough side elements to it that kept me as the watcher engaged and entertained and feeling for the characters as well. You got to see the human side of a character type that is stereotypically portrayed by Hollywood, IMHO, as being tough as nails and without feelings or remorse but instead just a robot. Not so with these two officers. If you enjoy a good cop drama, with good cops and not bad ones (think Denzel Washington in Training Day), you should really pick this up. The shooting style took a bit of getting used too, much like Homicide: Life On The Streets was an acquired taste so will this movie be for you. But you'll get used to it within the first few minutes and then it'll be a non-issue. You'll laugh, you'll cry and you'll feel like you know what it's like to see the things that real police officers in a sprawling urban environment like The City of Angels must go through. Enjoy the movie.

I saw the previews for this a few months ago and thought it looked interesting.  Two policemen take on the drug cartels?  Cool, right?

To be honest, I wish I had my 90 minutes back.  I didn't feel any chemistry between the two main characters, and everyone else's character development was pretty much non-existent.  Sure, the two officers told lots of jokes, but I never really cared about them.  What actual investigation did they do?  Why did they deserve to be killed?

How about the anatomy of the hit?  How was it scheduled?  Its plot wasn't developed at all--just phone call, gangbangers talk, then BANG.  What about the anatomy of the cartel?  How did it operate?  Who were its leaders?

The idea that a policeman would film his life was fine, but all the "Look at me!  I'm on camera!" really took time away from actually telling a story from multiple angles.  Just seemed like a whole bunch of crass dialogue between two guys, neither of whom had anything to say.

David Ayer does not shy away from raw stories.  He is a facile writer and edgy director responsible for such impressive films as Harsh Times, Street Kings, Training Day, S.W.A.T., The Fast and the Furious, Dark Blue and Ten.  In END OF WATCH he steps into another arena of manipulating the camera technique to emphasize not only the speed with which the LAPD must react but also the in-between moments when boredom bonds officers tightly and some hilarious buddy talk is born. What he achieves in END OF WATCH is probably the most realistic (albeit heinously gory and terrifying) footage of what cops do and how they live and survive in a series of incidents that boggle the mind.

Brian Taylor (Jake Gyllenhaal) and Mike Zavala (Michael Peña) are cop partners who do their job in a amazingly skillful manner and at the same time demonstrate that they have formed a brotherly bond that makes us identify with them immediately: Brian learns the ins and outs of marriage from Mike who is completely committed to this wife Gabby (Natalie Martinez) and Mike encourages Brian to commit to a relationship with his current love Janet (Anna Kendrick). In the midst of all of this bonding the two officers deal with car chases, child endangerment, drug cartels, human trafficking, and a horrendous confrontation with a Mexican drug cartel gang that leads to a brutal end to the story.

To capture the immediacy of both the good and bad aspects of the endangered lives of Brian and Mike the entire film is shot with hand held cameras, and surveillance cameras -a technique that director Ayers even endears his audience by having Brian be an addict to hand held cameras shooting the fun parts of their lives as well as the terrifying parts. The dialogue sounds spontaneous and is overwhelmed by expletives that in previous years would have been bleeped, but now with social media absorbing everyone's life the words are simply common language and keep the story real.

Gyllenhaal again serves notice that he is one of our more gifted actors on the screen today and Michael Peña's performance is so astonishing fine that it is Oscar worthy as Supporting Actor.  The other LAPD personnel given screen time include excellent portrayals by David Harbour, Frank Grillo, America Ferrera, and Cody Horn.  Both Anna Kendrick and Natalie Martinez are strong as are the actors who portray the gangsters.

The technique shooting this film, the dialogue, and the incessant picturing of horrendous scenes may be off putting to some, but it is good to see good cops doing what they do best - place their lives on the line to protect the citizenry. In all this is an outstanding film.  Grady Harp, January 13

"We stand watch together. The thin-blue-line, protecting the prey from the predators, the good from the bad. We are the police." Bryan (Gyllenhaal) and Mike (Pena) are two cops that patrol south central LA. They are good at what they do and aren't afraid to get their hands dirty. After a few stops they begin to uncover a ring run by a cartel that puts their lives in danger. I have to start by saying that this is a very good movie. The way that it is shot makes it even more interesting. The movie is filmed like a documentary and really adds another dimension to the film. Much like "Training Day" the movie is very gritty and realistic and some things they find are hard to watch. This is one of those movies that really seem to come out of no where and grabs you. This is a movie that you just need to experience and watch rather then read about. I highly recommend this movie. Overall, one of the best movies of year. I give it an A.

I wasn't sure what to think of 'End of Watch' when I saw previews for it but after seeing it all I can say is WOW! It's a pretty intense movie about 2 buddy cops patrolling the mean streets of Los Angeles. There's some pretty intense scenes throughout the entire movie mixed in with funny back and forth between Jake Gyllenhaal and Michael Pena.

Overall it's a great movie that I think everyone should see! Great comedy, drama and action all mixed into one great movie.
I recommend this movie for everyone except kids it is a buyer ! All cops should get this one it is us.

Jake Gyllenhaal and Michael Peña have a great chemistry in this movie and help to carry a fairly leaden script through the slower parts. They are easy to believe as good friends, partners and cop buddies and certainly the dialog lends itself to creating an authentic relationship between the two.

Unfortunately, the amateur-cam filming style is distracting and unnecessary and not even consistent throughout. It's never explained why all these separate parties are carrying video cameras and in certain scenes they revert back to an unknown third party camera presumably because they couldn't figure out how to put a camera in the scene (who's filming Gyllenhaal and Kendrick's love scenes?). All in all, it would have been a better film to shoot in a traditional way without having this distraction.

The main plot is slow to start too. The first act is spent showing what great cops our duo are and while we get to witness some exciting action, when the bad guys decide to take them down, it all feels very rushed. As a result, the film is very strong on character and atmosphere but the plot's not well structured enough to act less like TV and more like a movie.

Ultimately, End of Watch provides an exciting ride up to a point but after the film you don't feel you really discovered anything. It compares poorly with Training Day, David Ayer's earlier flick, which shows how well executed a detailed police procedural can be.

First of all, I am obliged to praise Gyllenhaal and Pena. Without their superb performance, the heavy use of camcorder shooting would be much less effective in making the film as real as it now appeared to be. Of course, the screenwriter/director deserved the credit for putting that much substance into a 109 min movie. Although a few reviewers commented that some parts of the story were unbelievable, I checked with my friends in LA and they said the real world is much worse in some preccints. In short, highly watchable for grown-ups!

p.s. 1) I salute to all good cops who sacrifice their biological and family lives for us! 2) If it were not for that sad ending I would have rated it a five stars! (Please forgive my....)

Please don't get the wrong idea from my title: I was a big fan of Training Day--and many other far more violent films--so I am not opposed to violence in films at all. I was expecting more of a thriller than a mockumentary, and the mockumentary style--in all its jiggle-cam glory--never quite did it for me. The acting was very solid but the story was cliched, predictable and took unnecessary cheap shots at times. The superb acting was the only thing that salvaged the film for me. By Jim Clark, publisher, Lee County Courier, Tupelo, Mississippi

End of Watch is story of two policemen working in rough South Central Los Angeles.
Brian Taylor (Jake Gyllenhaal) is a former U.S. Marine, who is about tired of being a player and looking for a one-man woman.
Miguel Zavala (Michael Pena) on the other hand married his high school sweetheart, has a child and a sense of community.
The two are best buds on the job, and off.
They take a public disturbance call. They find Tre, a large black man, with much attitude. He heckles Miguel with racial insults telling him he wouldn't be talking tough without the badge and gun. Egged on by his partner, Miguel drops his gear and accepts the fight. He wins winning the respect of the criminal.
The next call is missing children. They find the children duct-taped in the closet, the guardians stoned and lucid. Just another day at the office.
Taylor meets Janet, falls in love and marries her. Miguel and his wife, Gabby, have a second child.
At work they stumble upon ornate weapons, cash and a room full of trafficking victims. ICE agents warn them away, that this is cartel business. But the boys want to make a name for themselves, so start to investigate the source. Meanwhile the cartel puts out a kill order on the officers.
Gyllenhaal and Pena underwent five months of training for their roles, including 12-hour ride alongs through the toughest parts of L.A. Cool but very gritty and violent movie.

While I like Gyllenhall and his co-star, this is another of the movies that should have afforded a tripod. Because hand-held camera works is justified by a few lines in the script, I can understand the use of shaky camera in some scenes -- even though we are never told exactly what project Gyllenhall is working on that causes him to carry a camera. The movie is a series of episodes. I had some idea of what the plot was supposed to be, but I was still surprised that the movie seemed to be half-over before the first real plot element comes into the action. By the time the plot was underway I felt so nauseous from the camera motion that I had to walk-out. I actually did throw up.
I would like to know exactly how the movie ends, but what I saw of it, and the cliche nature of what I saw, I can guess at the ending -- and whatever I imagine is probably more creative that whatever writer/director David Ayer came up with.
Maybe this is more watchable on the small screen. I would not recommend it to anyone who is sensitive to motion sickness.
Great cop / buddy film. Was funny but intense and drama as well.  A must see. They played well off each other

Not  having seen this movie in the pastor even hearing much about the movie in the past I didn't know what to expect. I have to say that after watching the movie I was very surprised to find how powerful the movie was. the movie is a first-person narrative so you have to enjoy that type of movie as it makes you feel like you are part of the movie and with the characters as they go through the drama as well as the plot of the story that is being told. The actors within the movie did a great job and train their characters and it is a very raw look at law enforcement and the job they do. The movie attempts to show reality within law enforcement and to that end the ending of the movie is a much more reality-based ending then and some other movies of a similar topic. One of the things that I really liked about the movie was the relationship between the two main characters, as you really get to see the bond that has developed and develops in a partner relationship within law enforcement. This was a well conceptualized movie with good acting and great cinematography. The action and drama within the movie will keep you on the edge of your seat and leave you asking for more in the end.

Let me start by saying I completely changed my opinion of this film by the end of it. About 3 quarters of the way through, I was around a 2.5, but things really pick up in the film toward the end: emotionally and dramatically. There are a few things I really liked about this film, the biggest being the partnership of Jake Gyllenhaal and Michael Pena's characters. Fantastic chemistry here. There's a perfect balance of arguments, ball-busting, and serious conversation to be had here. I feel safe saying this is one of the best buddy-cop match ups EVER. There are quite a few laughs in this movie, which is rare in such a dark film. I liked Anna Kendrick in this (mostly because she is my current Hollywood crush). There was also a healthy balance of work and personal life, which in turn contributed to the great character development in this film. I felt myself REALLY caring about what happens to these characters, which is a rare feeling when you watch as many movies as I do. I was also pleasantly surprised with how emotionally charged this film was, especially at the end. Great performances from Gyllenhaal and Pena make this film good.

I won't elaborate on the many reasons why I am so opposed to the "found footage" approach, but I will say that one of those reasons is that it is so overused. Project X, Cloverfield, and Paranormal Activity are three films in recent memory that try and fail using this method. This film did a slightly better job at using this technique, but like all "found footage" films, I was left feeling dizzy nauseous. That is my biggest issue with this film. This easily could have been one of my favorite films of the year, but the use of this choppy, shaky shooting style takes away from the sophistication of the story. I can see how they were going for the "Cops" look, which could've been done better as TV show, but for film, this is a style that shouldn't be used. This also caused issues throughout the film because we were being beat over the head about where cameras were, and there were one too many "get that camera out of my face" moments. The documentary style seemed forced, and that definitely hurt the score for this film.

In conclusion, if the shaky-cam doesn't bother you, this is a good buddy-cop film that has a serious take on the drug war and is very emotional. Great performances from the leads helps distract you from the aesthetic problems in this film, but you will still leave the theater wishing you watched a "film" rather than a bunch of splices of footage. Recommended for buddy-cop and crime fans.

Interesting, moving, tense if sometimes uneven mix of very rough,
hand-held visual style, improvisational feeling acting, and occasionally
much more conventional plot turns. This study of two slightly gonzo,
gung-ho, but basically righteous Los Angeles cops is alternately deeply
engrossing and affecting, and occasionally frustrating.

When it all works, it feels about as real as any police drama I've ever
seen. (It's also too rare to see an heroic Hispanic lead character in a film
about a city where Latinos make up a huge part of the population)

When it gets in it's own way -- as when the camera-work becomes so
self-conscious that you start thinking about it (Why do so many
characters just happen to have cameras? Why are many of the shots from
angles that could never be from a home video camera, if this is
following a "found video" conceit?) or when the acting occasionally
stops feeling real and suddenly comes off as self- conscious improv. Or
when our heroes are in firefights that look real, but follow Hollywood
rules of logic as to how they turn out. At those points the film can be
maddening, just for undermining how good it is when it's on target.

Still, very worth seeing, and far more interesting than most of what
comes out of Hollywood.
I thought this to be a good movie. Its shot more like a documentary (kind of like cops). It was very enjoyable.

I was hesitant on watching this movie.  It looked like your average bang-bang shoot 'em up film, but went ahead and watched it.  From the start to the end, the movie had me entertained and drawn in waiting to see what happens next.  If you don't like the first 5 minutes of the film, then turn it off because it's probably not for you.  But if you do, keep watching because it only gets better.  I will have to say the movie is gory in the sense that it looks realistic.  The story line is great and makes you feel like your in the line of duty with the actors.  During the movie I found myself getting more attached to the characters which is what the movie was designed to do (obviously), but it plays an very important part for the ending.

What sets this movie apart is the ending (very end) which was a GREAT way to close the movie and is no where near being cliche.  This movie really is a work of art in which many have imitated, but few have done it correctly.  I would highly recommend seeing this movie. If you love action, suspense, brotherly love or cop movies you'll definitely like this one.  Even if you're an action junky this movie will keep your attention.  Everyone has different opinions, but I highly doubt you'll walk away from this one saying it sucked.

I didn't hear about this movie through the normal channels (i.e. media) infact I almost never heard about it at all if not by word of mouth recommendation from a friend. If you loved both Training Day and Cloverfield (which I do) then this movie is spectacular.. It is shot with a blend of true 'Blair Witch' stile of filming with similar 'Training Day' ride alongs in squad cars. The similarities end their however as 'End of Watch' has been modernized from the old 'Rampart' scandal (Training Day) to the current events of the ever encroaching run-amok drugs cartels and their increasing chock hold into American Lives. 'End of Watch' is in fact about a very serious topic but has a lot of racial humor (which is actually funny) mixed in, making their characters identifiable, and overall enjoyable to watch. Both Jake Gyllenhaal and Michael Pena did a great job with this script. This movie was a great watch and I'm sure their will be many more who will feel the same.

While I have seen better stories on episodes of Southland, the strength of the film rests on the tremendous acting of the the two leads Pena and Gyllenhaal.  The outstanding dialogue of Ayer paired with the leads natural patter create a portrayal of real male friendship that is rarely seen in film.  The failure of this movie is one of what is could have been if this acting was wrapped around a more compelling narrative.  While Ayer might have purposely have constructed it this way the purpose failed to draw me into this story. And telling stories is the point of movies...

I didn't have much expectations for this move it be honest, the TV trailers made it look like a just another cop movie a la Training Day (not that there is anything wrong with that) but I am a bit jaded of those. To my delight and surprise the movie turned into a very good movie that despite its "buddy cop" influences. The performances of both leads Jake Gyllenhaal & Michael Pea (with an always delightful Anna Kendrick) are simply stunning, and the "reality show" camera movement and angles gives the movie a really kinetic feel where you never feel lost in what is going on and it is exciting and dynamic. The premise of the movie is simple, a pair of LA cops, whose relationship goes beyond the job is he backdrop for an overreaching plot where both cops are targeted by a Mexican cartel. It looked like a popcorn movie but it turned out to be surprisingly well done, with some great performances all around and highly recommended.

Absolutely stunning film that will stay with you long after you've seen it. Likely a 2012 Best Picture nominee and both male leads deserve Oscar nods. The chemistry between the two leads is striking and authentic. The mood is dark and menacing. Truly the best cop/South Central L.A. movie ever made.

After Source Code, I promised myself to watch every Jake Gylenhaal film and I can assure you I wasn't disappointed.

End of watch is easily the film of the year for me so far. The acting is terrific, the script is tight, an absolute powerhouse performance by both Gylenhaal and Michael Pena.

I strongly recommend this film.

Two cops [Michael Pena and Jake Gyllenhall] fight crime in the dangerous streets of South Central Los Angeles. Their lives become chaotic when they stumble upon a human smuggling ring which in turn makes them the targets of a very deadly mexican drug cartel. This movie was very captivating and the found-footage technique that was used in this movie only enhanced the story even further. The acting was excellent by all of those involved especially the two performances of Michael Pena and Jake Gyllenhall [these two guys need to be nominated for oscars next year]. I also love how this movie has a great sense of humor throughout without it taking away from the overall feel of the movie. Over the course of the movie, You really begin to like and appreciate the efforts of the two main characters to fight crime in one of the most dangerous cities in America as the many scenes of the two main characters conversing in their squad car really provide some of the most entertaining scenes of the movie [as well as some of the funniest]. Also, the comedic scenes really do prepare your heart for the more disturbing events that occur as the film progresses [trust me, things get very ugly in the second half of the movie]. Compared to the many cop movies that have came before it, End Of Watch certainly is one of the most down to earth and realistic police drama's you'll ever have the privelege of seeing. And while this movie is often hillarious, be prepared for some disturbing scenes and especially be prepared for a very sad ending. If you miss this in the theatres, You owe it to yourself to see this powerful movie as soon as it hits DVD and Blu-Ray! In my opinion, this movie deserves to be nominated for the best picture Oscar in 2013. STRONGLY reccomended

End of Watch realistically portrays the reality of cop life on the rough streets of south central LA.

It tells the story of two partners Brian (Jake Gyllenhal) and Mike (Michael Pena). At first it appears more like a documentary than a movie, and highlights the camaraderie between officers and rivalry within the dept.

The opening scene featuring a high speed chase on a dash cam followed by a fatal encounter is all shot through the single cam with editing. I found this to be quite impressive giving a realistic feel.

As the movie progresses it seems driven more by events than by story which I personally found to be a refreshing change from typical cop movies. As it lacks the slick production you typically get in a police procedural it invites us into a more realistic experience.

Brian is the more introspective cop who used to be in the Armed Forces, and Michael the more gregarious one. There is great chemistry and humor between these two, as they discuss their dreams, first times and so forth.

The story emerges when these two accidentally uncover a human trafficking operation and run foul of a Mexican drug cartel. Brian's curious nature leads him to ignore the advice of a DEA agent and follow up some leads himself, which has potentially fatal consequences for he and his partner.

We explore the romantic relationships of these two, one married, the other just beginning a relationship with a girl played by Anna Kendrick (Up in the Air).

We explore the interactions with different villains one of whom challenges Mike to put down his weapons and see if he can take him physically. A fight ensues. The ultimate outcome of this fight may save both cops lives.

Brian carries a camera with him giving a cops eye view on several scenes. Sometimes this did seem impractical and a little dangerous and unrealistic, and sometimes I did find the shifting between perspectives a little jarring. Later though this does become interesting with the climactic scenes.

I think the best way to watch this movie is not to know too much about it in advance and just experience it. I found the experience to be well worthwhile and was thankful to be able to see it while still in theaters. I think though there is little advantage to seeing it in theater compared to waiting for the dvd.

It surpassed my expectations and I think it did portray the policemen as flawed but quintessentially good and also heroic. I think most people will love it.

End of Watch is a forgettable title for a film which tries tremendously hard to be something more than it is: namely, a one-dimensional cop-buddy movie. Director David Ayer throws all sorts of modern lo-fi tricks at the screen to hustle up an authentic gritty vibe and achieves it, but then lets himself down with an orthodox and ultimately unambitious screenplay beset with cartoon villainy. The result is still an entertaining couple of hours, supported by strong performances from both leads and the supporting cast.

Set in South Central Los Angeles, officers Taylor (Jake Gyllenhaal) and Zavala (Michael Pea) are harness bulls with the LAPD who have a penchant for stumbling into situations beyond their pay grade: while Sarge (Frank Grillo) constantly exhorts them to be out there writing tickets, the boys can't help themselves: an opening sequence shows them pursuing then (justifiably) shooting dead armed offenders, and later, even a casual check in on a missing old lady turns up a huge cocaine shipment, a people smuggling operation and a mass of tortured and murdered immigrants.

Cinema vrit is provided courtesy of a filming style which you'll love or hate: being an aspiring amateur filmmaker, Taylor carries about his person several product-placed Canon handycams and about four "flip" recorders, and so we mostly watch early exchanges through his own, and jerky, erratic camera work. When the camera needs to be still to dispatch with plot exposition and character establishment, the director contrives to mounted it on the dash of the boys' Black & White, and is not averse splicing in to aerial shots and other conventional cinematic frames, somewhat giving the lie to the "found footage" intent. In any case, after a nauseating ten minute spell at the beginning, the framing does settle down a bit.

Now it is one thing having an aspiring film school police officer toting a camera World's-Scariest-Police-Chases style: it is another for the criminals he's pursuing to do the same thing. Both the not-so-bad African American gang and the baaad Mexican gang are obliged by this filming decision to be also compulsively filming themselves as they go about their gangster business. For a film which takes so many cues in its dialogue and attitude from The Wire, it well and truly missed this one: there's no way Omar or the boy Marlo would be seen dead on handycam; least of all in flagrante delicto shooting up the neighbourhood.

Things trundle on: in candid in in-car conversations we better get to know the boys, who reveal themselves to be good, well-intentioned lads, if crime-prone, and with loving families, and or at least designs on them. And then, without really the dramatic impetus to suggest it, suddenly everything goes wrong. It seems the really, really baaaaaaad dudes down in Mexico are finally sick of these troublesome priests, and resolve through their local agents to do something about it: We have arrived at the final reel. Ayer does not disappoint, although he does then tack on a bizarre coda after the action is complete that I can't fathom, other than as a means of providing a stronger up-beat to the finale.

This is an entertaining but, at its extremities, slightly potty film. Performances from the leads are all strong - Gyllenhaal and Pea are excellent, but cracks are visible in its heavy reliance on style, and weakly scripted villains.

Olly Buxton
